0OA31D0F.title: Microporous metal–organic frameworks constructed by Cu(I)/Zn(II), Tpt and 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate
0OA31D0F.abstract: Two novel metal–organic frameworks, [Cu(tpt)(bdc) 1/2 ] n · n H 2 O ( 1 ) and [Zn(tpt)(bdc) 1/2 I] n ( 2 ) (tpt = 2,4,6-tris(4-pyridyl)-1,3,5-triazine, H 2 bdc = 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid), have been prepared by hydrothermal reactions. In complex 1 , Cu(I) center is in a trigonal coordination environment with bidentate tpt coordinating Cu(I) atoms to form 1D zigzag chains, and bdc ligand links the zigzag chains to form a 2D layered structure. In complex 2 , Zn(II) center is in a trigonal–pyramidal environment with bidentate tpt coordinating Zn(II) atoms to form zigzag chains, and bdc links the zigzag chains to form metal–organic framework which contains interesting hexagonal nano-channels. Keywords Cu(I)/Zn(II) complex metal–organic framework Crystal structure 2,4,6-Tris(4-pyridyl)-1,3,5-triazine 1,4-Benzenedicarboxylate The design and assembly of metal–organic frameworks are of great interest due to their intriguing structural motifs and potential applications in functional materials [1–3] . Multipyridyl and polycarboxylate ligands have received considerable attention owing to the variety of their coordination modes and structures of metal complexes [4] . The trigonal ligand 2,4,6-tris(4-pyridyl)-1,3,5-triazine (tpt) is of specially interest in recent years, as this essentially planar ligand has already afforded a number of unusual and high symmetrical metal–organic frameworks [5] . Usually tpt is an exo-tridentate ligand, and the N atoms of three pyridyl groups can bind to different metal atoms. Its rigidity and triangular geometry can lead to formation of porous frameworks enclosing nano-porous cages [6,7] , cavities [8,9] , chambers [10] , and channels [11–13] . Although considerable studies have been done on metal-tpt two-component frameworks, the mixed-ligand metal–organic frameworks containing tpt and other bridging organic ligands are less reported until now. 1,4-Benzenedicarboxylate (bdc) can act as good building block in constructing metal–organic frameworks [14,15] , which possesses two carboxylate groups and exhibit varied coordinate modes. This makes it very appealing for design of metal–organic frameworks with interesting structures and properties. To assemble mixed-ligand metal–organic frameworks of tpt and bdc, hydrothermal synthesis should be powerful method, because tpt and biscarboxylate complexes often exhibit poor solubility. We report here two interesting microporous metal–organic frameworks constructed by Cu(I)/Zn(II), tpt and bdc. Hydrothermal reaction [16] of Cu(NO 3 ) 2 , tpt, H 2 bdc and piperidine in a molar ratio of 2:1:1:2 at 180 °C yields [Cu(tpt)(bdc) 1/2 ] n · n H 2 O ( 1 ), while hydrothermal reaction of ZnI 2 , tpt, H 2 bdc and piperidine in a molar ratio of 2:1:1:2 at 160 °C yields [Zn(tpt)(bdc) 1/2 I] n ( 2 ). Here piperidine acts as organic base. The X-ray structure analysis [17] revealed that complex 1 has a two-dimensional layered framework. As shown in Fig. 1 , each asymmetric structure unit contains one crystallographically independent copper(I) atom, one tpt and half of bdc ligand. The Cu(1) atom is in a trigonal coordination environment and coordinates to two pyridyl N atoms from different tpt and one O atom of bdc. The bond angles of N(1)–Cu(1)–N(6A), N(1)–Cu(1)–O(1) and O(1)–Cu(1)–N(6A) are 153.01(12), 99.85(11), 106.69(11)°, respectively. Each tpt ligand binds to two copper(I) centers through two pyridyl N atoms, while the third pyridyl N atom is uncoordinated. The bond lengths of Cu(1)–N(1) and Cu(1)–N(6A) are 1.923(3), 1.908(3) Å, respectively. Two carboxylate groups of bdc coordinate to two copper(I) centers in a monodentate mode. The Cu(1)–O(1) bond length is 2.289(3) Å. Generally, tpt shows exo-tridentate coordinate mode in coordination polymers. In complex 1 , tpt acting as bidentate ligand bridges Cu(I) atoms to form one-dimensional zigzag chains. 1,4-Benzenedicarboxylate links the zigzag chains to form 2D layered structure. This framework exhibits large irregular rings, each constructing from four tpt, two bdc ligands and six Cu(I) atoms. In recent decade, 4,4′-bipyridine has been widely used as bidentate bridging ligand to construct one-dimensional linear chains [19] . While constructing 1D zigzag chains, bidentate tpt ligand may be a good molecular building block because of its 120° rigid angle [20] . In complex 2 , the asymmetric structure unit contains one zinc(II) atom, one coordinated I − , one tpt and half of bdc ligand ( Fig. 2 ). Zn(1) atom locates at the core of a distorted trigonal–pyramidal geometry. The basal plane is constructed by the coordination of N(1), O(1) and I(1). The bond lengths of Zn(1)–N(1), Zn(1)–O(1) and Zn(1)–I(1) are 2.052(4), 1.933(3), 2.5314(7) Å, respectively. The bond angles of N(1)–Zn(1)–O(1), N(1)–Zn(1)–I(1) and O(1)–Zn(1)–I(1) are 115.30(15), 114.58(10), 119.81(11)°, respectively. The axial position is occupied by N(5A) atom with the Zn(1)–N(5A) bond length of 2.090(4) Å. The bond angle of N(1)–Zn(1)–N(5A) is 100.31(14)°. Other bond lengths and angles are normal as expected. Analogous to the coordination mode of tpt in copper complex 1 , tpt binds to two Zn(II) centers through two pyridyl N atoms, while the third pyridyl N atom is free. Tpt acting as bidentate bridging ligand links Zn(II) atoms to form zigzag chains. Both carboxylate groups of 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate coordinate to Zn(II) centers in a monodentate mode. The bdc ligand acting as μ 2 -bridge links Zn(tpt)I zigzag chains to form microporous metal–organic framework. Along the b -axis, the framework exhibits intriguing hexagonal nano-channels ( Fig. 3 ). In each hexagonal channel, two of the six edges are π -faces of bdc units and the other four edges are built by tpt ligands. The approximate dimensions of the hexagonal channels are 1.23 nm × 1.63 nm. Comparing the structures of 1 and 2 , the former exhibits a trigonal coordination geometry around Cu(I) centers with 153.01° bond angle of N(1)–Cu(1)–N(6A), while the latter shows a trigonal–pyramidal geometry around Zn(II) centers with 100.31° angle of N(1)–Zn(1)–N(5A). Such arrangements result in the structural difference of metal-tpt zigzag chains and metal–organic frameworks. In conclusion, two novel microporous metal–organic frameworks have been assembled by tpt and 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate ligands. The frameworks consist of Cu(I)/Zn(II)-tpt zigzag chains and bdc bidentate bridges. The Zn(II) complex exhibits intriguing hexagonal nano-channels. AK99yPca.title: Stereoselective synthesis of trans-2-thien-α-oyl-3-[(un)substituted phenyl]-4-acetyl-5-methyl-2,3-dihydrofurans
AK99yPca.abstract: Trans-2-thien-α-oyl-3-[(un)substituted phenyl]-4-acetyl-5-methyl-2,3- dihydrofurans 3 were prepared in good yields with high stereoselectivity by the reaction of thien-α-oylmethyltriphenylarsonium bromide 1 with 3-[(un)substituted benzylidene]-2,4-pentadione 2 in benzene in the presence of potassium carbonate at 55°C. The structure of compound 3 was confirmed by IR, MS, 1H NMR, 1H-1H COSY, microanalysis and single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis. The possible reaction mechanism for the formation of products was also proposed. © 2008 SIOC, CAS, & Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA.

eLtkJ3Js.title: Diaquaazido(3,5-diaminobenzoato-κN)-(1,10-phenanthroline- κ2N,N′)zinc(II) monohydrate
eLtkJ3Js.abstract: The reaction of 3,5-diaminobenzoic acid, 1,10-phenanthroline, NaN 3 and ZnII in basic aqueous solution gave rise to the title compound, [Zn(C7H7N2O2)(N 3)(C12H8N2)(H2O) 2] · H2O. The ZnII atom is six-coordinate with a distorted octahedral geometry. The two aqua ligands are in cis positions and the 3,5-diaminobenzoate ligand binds to the central Zn atom through one of its amino groups. © 2006 International Union of Crystallography All rights reserved.

dCF6wxBk.title: Cu(II)/Cd(II) coordination polymers based on polycarboxylate and 2-(2-pyridyl)benzimidazole

zCdmfLBK.title: Metal-organic frameworks constructed from 2,4,6-Tris(4-pyridyl)-1,3,5-triazine.
zCdmfLBK.abstract: Five new metal-organic frameworks based on 2,4,6-tris(4-pyridyl)-1,3,5-triazine (tpt) ligand have been hydrothermally synthesized. Reaction of tpt and AgNO 3 in an acidic solution at 180 degrees C yields {[Ag(Htpt)(NO3)]NO(3).4H2O}n (1).Ag(I) is trigonally coordinated by two pyridyl nitrogen and one nitrato oxygen to form a 1D zigzag chain. Reaction of tpt with CuSO4 affords {[Cu2(tpt)2(SO4)2(H2O)2].4H2O}n (2). Copper(II) is bonded to two pyridyl nitrogen, two sulfato oxygen, and two water oxygen atoms to form an elongated octahedral geometry. Each H2O ligand bridges two copper(II), whereas sulfate bridges copper(II) via micro-1,3 and micro-1,1 fashions. The copper(II)-sulfate-H2O2D layers are linked by bidentate tpt to form a 3D polymeric structure. Reaction of Cu(SO4)2, tpt, and 1,2,4,5-benzenetetracarboxylic acid (H4btec) in the presence of piperidine gives [Cu(tpt)(H2btec)1/2]n (3). Copper(I) is located in a trigonal-pyramidal coordination environment and coordinated by three pyridyl nitrogen of tpt in a plane, whereas a carboxylate oxygen is coordinated to the copper(I) axially. The tpt-Cu forms a layer, and the layers are linked through H 2btec2- to form a 2D double-layered coordination polymer. Replacing CuSO4 with ZnI2 in the synthesis gives {[Zn(tpt)(btec)1/2].H2O}n (4). Zinc(II) is in a distorted tetrahedral geometry and linked through bidentate tpt and exotetradentate btec4- to form a 2D coordination grid. Reaction of tpt with CuCN leads to the assembly of a 3D metal-organic framework [Cu3(CN)3(tpt)]n (5). Copper(I) is trigonally coordinated by one pyridyl nitrogen and two cyanides to form an intriguing honeycomb architecture. Luminescence study shows that 1, 3, 4, and 5 have blue fluorescence, which can be assigned to be ligand-centered emissions. Thermal analysis shows that all of these complexes are quite stable, and especially for 4, the framework is stable up to 430 degrees C.

CWlZwAUR.title: Facile synthesis of 2-perfluoroalkylated benzoxazolines and benzothiazolines
CWlZwAUR.abstract: The synthesis of 2-perfluoroalkylated benzoxazolines and benzothiazolines was easily achieved under mild conditions in high yields and purity. The protocol uses readily available methyl 2-perfluoroalkynoates as fluorine-containing building block, and furnished the expected product in good to excellent yields in MeOH under reflux for 10 h. This novel synthetic protocol is efficient and general. A plausible mechanism for this process is proposed. © 2013 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.

IeeHoHlP.title: Syntheses, crystal structures and magnetic property of two azido-bridged coordination polymers with 1,2-diaminocyclohexane as co-ligand
IeeHoHlP.abstract: Two azido-bridged coordination polymers, [Ni(L)(μ 1,1 -N 3 ) 2 ] ( 1 ) and [Cu(L)(μ 1,1,3 -N 3 )(N 3 )] ( 2 ) (L = 1,2-diaminocyclohexane), have been synthesized and characterized by elemental analyses, IR spectra and X-ray structural analyses. Complex 1 is a one-dimensional helical chain coordination polymer with both azides as μ 1,1 -bridge, which exhibits interesting wheel motif. Complex 2 shows two-dimensional layer network in which an azide acts as μ 1,1,3 -bridge and the other azide as monodentate ligand. Cyclic voltammogram gives quasi-reversible redox wave of Cu(II)/Cu(I) pair. Variable-temperature magnetic property of 1 was investigated, which shown strong ferromagnetic interaction arising from the μ 1,1 -azido bridging nickel(II) chains. Keywords Azide 1,2-Diaminocyclohexane Coordination polymer Crystal structure Magnetic property

AzU3qFmd.title: Highly stereoselective construction of spiro[cyclopropane-1,4′-pyrazolin-5′-one]with 4-arylidene-3-methyl-1-phenyl-pyrazolin-5-one and arsonium ylide
AzU3qFmd.abstract: A highly stereoselective synthesis of exo-spiro[cyclopropane-1,4′-pyrazolin-5′-one] from 4-arylidene-3-methyl-1-phenyl-pyrazolin-5-one and arsonium bromide in the presence of base has been achieved. The triphenylarsine-catalyzed cyclopropanation of 4-arylidene-3-methyl-1-phenyl-pyrazolin-5-one with bromide in the presence of NaHCO3 has also been studied. Both exo and endo isomers were formed in this reaction. The structures of the products were characterized by IR, MS, 1H NMR, elemental analysis, and X-ray diffraction analysis. © 2008 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.

ZqGvTZIC.title: Copper(I)-catalyzed intermolecular cyclization of methyl perfluoroalk-2-ynoates with o-aminophenyl ketones: Access to 2-perfluoroalkylated quinolines
ZqGvTZIC.abstract: One-pot, two-step cyclization of o-aminophenyl ketones 1 and methyl perfluoroalk-2-ynoates 2 takes place in the presence of copper(I) as catalyst and diisopropylethylamine as base, leading to 2-perfluoroalkylated quinolines. Compared with previous methods that have been used to generate quinoline skeletons, this technique uses inexpensive copper salt as catalyst, methyl perfluoroalk-2-ynoate as fluorinated building block and proceeds smoothly under mild conditions, which makes the transformation both sustainable and practical. Copper(I)-catalyzed, one-pot, two-step cyclization of o-aminophenyl ketones 1 and methyl perfluoroalk-2-ynoates 2 in the presence of diisopropylethylamine leading to 2-perfluoroalkylated quinolines 3 proceeds smoothly under mild conditions. Copyright © 2013 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim.

xiZaFS6H.title: μ-Biphenyl-3,3′,4,4′-tetra-carboxyl-ato-κ2 O 3:O 3′-bis-[triaqua-(2,2′-bipyridyl- κ2 N,N′)nickel(II)] hexa-hydrate
xiZaFS6H.abstract: The asymmetric unit of the title complex, [Ni2(C16H6O8)(C10H8N2)2(H2O)6] ·6H2O, contains one NiII atom, one 2,2′-bipyridine ligand, three coordinated water mol-ecules, one-half of a fully deprotonated biphenyl-3,3′,4,4′-tetra-carboxyl-ate anion and three lattice water mol-ecules. The NiII atom displays a distorted NiN2O4 octa-hedral coordination formed by one carboxyl-ate O atom, three water O atoms and two N atoms of the chelating ligand. The complete biphenyl-3,3′,4,4′- tetra-carboxyl-ate ligand displays inversion symmetry and links two symmetry-related NiII atoms into a binuclear complex. Neighbouring complex mol-ecules are linked through O - H⋯O hydrogen bonds into a three-dimensional structure. Additional O - H⋯O hydrogen bonds between the lattice water mol-ecules help to consolidate the crystal packing.

9E3Iq43u.title: Monomeric and polymeric structures derived from 3,3′,4,4′-biphenyltetracarboxylic acid, phenanthroline and metal ions
9E3Iq43u.abstract:
Under similar hydrothermal synthetic conditions, the reactions of Fe(NO3)3/FeCl2, CuCl2, NiCl2, and CdCl2 with phenanthroline (phen) and 3,3′,4,4′-biphenyltetracarboxylic acid (H4BPTC) afforded complexes [Fe(phen)3](H3BPTC)2 (1), [Cu(phen)(BPTC)0.5 · H2O] · H2O (2), [Ni3(phen)3(BPTC)1.5(H2O)5] · 4H2O (3) and [Cd(phen)(BPTC)0.5] · H2O (4). The short Fe–N distance in the monomeric Fe(phen)3(H3 BPTC)2 (1) shows that the Fe(II) is in a low-spin state. H3 BPTC4− acts as a counter-ion in this complex. In [Cu(phen)(BPTC)0.5 · H2O] · H2O (2), the central Cu(II) is five-coordinated in a square-pyramidal geometry. The ligand BPTC4− is centrosymmetric and the four deprotonated carboxylic groups of BPTC4− are coordinated to four different copper ions to form a 1D ladder complex indicating a comparatively strong coordination.
 In [Ni3(phen)3(BPTC)1.5(H2O)5] · 4H2O (3), all nickel(II) atoms are in an octahedral coordination environment. There are two different BPTC4− ligands; one is centrosymmetric and the other is asymmetric. Metal ions are linked through fully deprotonated BPTC4− ligands to form a 2D metal-organic sheet. [Cd(phen)(BPTC)0.5] · H2O (4) has a 3D metal-organic framework. TG, IR, and fluorescence data for the complexes are presented.

ZZJUE5xp.title: Unusual metal–organic network constructed from Zn(II), benzenetricarboxylate and bis(1,2,4-triazolyl)pyridine
ZZJUE5xp.abstract: A metal–organic network {[Zn 3 (btp) 2 (btc) 2 (H 2 O) 2 ] · 4H 2 O} n ( 1 ) and a supramolecular cocrystal [H 3 btc · btp · H 2 O] n ( 2 ) were synthesized and structurally characterized. Complex 1 exhibits an unusual polymeric network contains two molecular squares and a rectangle. Abstract Hydrothermal reaction of ZnSO 4 · 7H 2 O with 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (H 3 btc) and 2,6-bis(1,2,4-triazolyl)pyridine (btp) afforded a novel metal–organic network {[Zn 3 (btc) 2 (btp) 2 (H 2 O) 2 ] · 4H 2 O} n ( 1 ) with a supramolecular cocrystal [H 3 btc · btp · H 2 O] n ( 2 ). The complex 1 exhibits an unusual network containing two molecular squares and a rectangle. The networks interpenetrate to make a 3D metal–organic framework, which is quite thermal stable. Compound 2 shows a 2D supramolecular network assembled through strong hydrogen bonds. Keywords 1,3,5-Benzenetricarboxylic acid 2,6-Bis(1,2,4-triazolyl)pyridine Metal–organic framework Crystal structure Porous metal–organic frameworks are of great interest due to their intriguing structural motifs as well as potential applications in functional materials, such as catalysis, zeolite-like porous material, and hydrogen-storage material [1–3] . Much effort has been focused on the design and controlled synthesis of porous metal–organic frameworks. The diversity in such framework structures greatly depends on the selection of metal ions, organic ligands and reaction pathways. Polycarboxylate, multipyridyl and triazolate ligands have received considerable attention in constructing metal–organic frameworks owing to the variety of their coordination modes [4,5] . Our strategy has involved the use of mixed ligands such as polycarboxylate and N -heterocyclic ligands for creating novel framework structures [6] . The rigid trigonal ligand 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (H 3 btc) is of specially interest in recent years, because this essentially planar ligand has already afforded a number of unusual multidimensional metal–organic frameworks [7,8] . 1,2,4-Triazole and its derivatives are also of increasing interest in constructing coordination polymers. 2,6-Bis(1,2,4-triazolyl)pyridine (btp) possesses seven potential N -donor atoms, which makes it very appealing for design of coordination polymers with interesting structures and properties. However, only two btp complexes have been documented to date [9,10] . Herein, we report an unusual metal–organic network {[Zn 3 (btc) 2 (btp) 2 (H 2 O) 2 ] · 4H 2 O} n ( 1 ) and a supramolecular cocrystal [H 3 btc · btp · H 2 O] n ( 2 ). A mixture of ZnSO 4 · 7H 2 O (0.2 mmol), H 3 btc (0.2 mmol), btp (0.2 mmol) and water (10 mL) was sealed in a 15 mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel reactor, which was heated at 120 °C for 3 days under autogenous pressure. Upon cooling to room temperature at a rate of 10 °C h −1 , a mixture of colorless block crystals 1 and colorless stick-like crystals 2 were obtained. The yield for 1 is 30% based on Zn. Complex 1 : elemental anal. calcd for C 18 H 16 N 7 O 9 Zn 1.5 : C 37.77, H 2.82, N 17.13; found: C 38.37, H 2.73, N 17.27. IR (KBr, cm −1 ): 3417(m), 3153(w), 3083(m), 1609(s), 1575(s), 1529(s), 1473(s), 1438(s), 1361(s), 1059(m), 763(m), 732(s), 634(m). Compound 2 : IR (KBr, cm −1 ): 3609(m), 3535(m), 3119(m), 1708(s), 1608(m), 1513(m), 1467(m), 1238(s), 1053(m), 803(m), 747(m), 679(m), 633(w). Both complexes can be prepared alone. A mixture of ZnSO 4 · 7H 2 O (0.3 mmol), H 3 btc (0.2 mmol), btp (0.2 mmol) and water (10 mL) heated at 160 °C for 3 days afforded complex 1 with 65% yield, while the mixture of H 3 btc (0.2 mmol), btp (0.2 mmol) and water (10 mL) heated at 160 °C for 3 days afforded compound 2 with 60% yield. The characteristic strong vibration absorptions of carboxyl groups appear at 1609, 1708 cm −1 for 1 and 2 , respectively, which indicates that the 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid is deprotonated in 1 and protonated in 2 . X-ray structural analysis [11] revealed that complex 1 is a 3D metal–organic network constructed through mixed ligands. As shown in Fig. 1 a, the asymmetric unit contains one and half crystallographically independent zinc(II) ions, a btp and a btc 3− ligand, as well as a coordinated water and two lattice water molecules. Zn(1) atom sits on two-fold rotation axis. It is in a distorted tetrahedral coordination environment and coordinates to two triazole nitrogen atoms and two carboxylate oxygen atoms belong to different btp and btc ligands. The bond distances of Zn(1)–O(6) and Zn(1)–N(6A) are 1.960(2), 2.044(2) Å, respectively. Zn(2) atom is in a distorted trigonal–pyramidal coordination environment and coordinates to a triazole N, a water O(1w) and two carboxylate O atoms. The basal plane is constructed by the coordination of N(1), O(2) and O(4A). The bond angles of N(1)–Zn(2)–O(2), N(1)–Zn(2)–O(4A) and O(2)–Zn(2)–O(4A) are 98.73(9), 124.09(10), 134.46(11)°, respectively. The water O(1w) occupies the axial position with Zn(2)–O(1w) bond length of 2.044(2) Å and the bond angle of O(1w)–Zn(2)–O(2) 93.85(10)°. Other bond lengths and angles are normal as expected. Three carboxyl groups of 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid are all deprotonated and coordinated to three Zn(II) atoms in a monodentate mode. 2,6-Bis(1,2,4-triazolyl)pyridine acts as a bidentate bridging ligand links two Zn(II) atoms through two triazole N atoms. Both multidentate ligands assembled with Zn(II) atoms forms a polymeric network. Interestingly, this network contains two kinds of molecular squares and a rectangle ( Fig. 1 b). One square is constructed by four bpt edges (1.14 nm × 1.14 nm), the other square is constructed by four btc edges (0.95 nm × 0.95 nm). A rectangle is formed by two bpt edges and two btc edges (1.14 nm × 0.95 nm) and held between four squares. Although polymeric network consisting of sole molecular square is common, the network containing different molecular squares is quite rare [13] . To our knowledge, complex 1 is the first coordination network containing two molecular squares and a rectangle. In complex 1 , 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylate is a tridentate linker with a central triangular unit which is linked to three Zn(II) atoms [14] . The bidentate 2,6-bis(1,2,4-triazolyl)pyridine ligand can be simplified as a rod-like linker. Thus the polymeric network of 1 can be described clearly through a topologic structure ( Fig. 1 c). There are two square tunnels and a rectangular tunnel in this topologic structure. Further research found that three such networks interpenetrate to each other, leading to the formation of a dense 3D metal–organic framework ( Fig. 1 d). Compound 2 is a 1:1 cocrystal of 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid with 2,6-bis(1,2,4-triazolyl)pyridine. In Fig. 2 , the asymmetric unit contains H 3 btc, btp and water molecule. Bond lengths and angles are normal as expected [15] . Btp is twisted with a dihedral angle of 21.03° between two triazole groups and pyridyl plane. Different with the structure of 1 , the carboxyl groups of H 3 btc are all protonated in cocrystal compound of 2 . Three carboxyl groups of H 3 btc link three triazole nitrogen atoms through strong O—H⋯N hydrogen bonds (donor to acceptor distances from 2.654(2) to 2.733(2) Å). Water molecule connects two carboxyl oxygen atoms through weak O(7)—H⋯O hydrogen bonds (average 2.934 Å). The sixth carboxyl oxygen shows weak H-bonding interaction with triazole C(6) atom (C(6)—H⋯O(5) 3.20 Å). Through these intermolecular hydrogen bonds interactions, the organic molecules and water are assembled into a two-dimensional supramolecular network as shown in Fig. 2 . TG-DTA curves of 1 were measured from 20 to 800 °C in air ( Fig. 3 ). The lattice water and coordinated water molecules were released in the temperature range of 140–190 °C (found 10.33%, calcd. 9.43%). Dehydrated [Zn 3 (btc) 2 (btp) 2 ] n framework kept thermal stable until 340 °C. Two weight-loss steps appeared in 340–370 °C and 380–500 °C ranges, which indicated a complicated process of 2,6-bis(1,2,4-triazolyl)pyridine released and 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylate decomposed. This process may lead to the formation of intermediate product Zn(HCO 3 ) 2 (found 46.36%, calcd. 49.11%) [16] . The last weight-loss step (530–800 °C) corresponded to a decomposed process of Zn(HCO 3 ) 2 with the final residue ZnO left (found 26.73%, calcd. 21.33%). In conclusion, a novel metal–organic network {[Zn 3 (btc) 2 (btp) 2 (H 2 O) 2 ] · 4H 2 O} n ( 1 ) with a supramolecular cocrystal [H 3 btc · btp · H 2 O] n ( 2 ) have been prepared hydrothermally. Complex 1 exhibits unusual network containing two molecular squares and a rectangle. The result has proven that 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid and 2,6-bis(1,2,4-triazolyl)pyridine are good molecular building blocks in constructing porous metal–organic frameworks and supramolecular compounds. Acknowledgements Financially supported by the Research Foundation for Returned Chinese Scholars Overseas of Chinese Education Ministry (7A14219), and the Development Foundation of Shanghai Education Commission (03AK35). Appendix A Supplementary material CCDC 645360 and 652451 contain the supplementary crystallographic data for 1 and 2 . These data can be obtained free of charge or from the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre, 12 Union Road, Cambridge CB2 1EZ, UK; fax: +44 1223 336 033; via http://www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/conts/retrieving.html , or e-mail: deposit@ccdc.cam.ac.uk . l66piN5N.title: Ferromagnetic and mixed-valence copper coordination polymers assembled by polycarboxylates and 2,6-bis(1,2,4-triazolyl)pyridine
l66piN5N.abstract: Hydrothermal reactions of Cu(NO 3 ) 2 with 2,6-bis(1,2,4-triazolyl)pyridine (btp) and 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (H 3 btc) or 1,2,4,5-benzenetetracarboxylic acid (H 4 btec) in base aqueous solution afford two novel complexes [Cu 2 (btp)(btc)(H 2 O)(OH)] n ( 1 ) and [Cu 2 (btp)(Hbtec)] n · n H 2 O ( 2 ). Complex 1 is a coordination polymer where a carboxylate and a hydroxyl are bound to Cu(II) ions to form (μ-OH)(μ-O 2 CR)Cu 2 core, which is ferromagnetic couple with 2 J = 21.30 cm −1 . Complex 2 is a 3-D coordination polymer. Bond valence sum (BVS) analysis indicates it is a mixed-valence compound. Cu(I) is three-coordinated by triazole N-donors, while Cu(II) is four-coordinated by a triazole N and three carboxyl O-donors. Both complexes are quite thermal stable. Keywords Copper complex Crystal structure 2,6-Bis(1,2,4-triazolyl)pyridine 1,3,5-Benzenetricarboxylic acid 1,2,4,5-Benzenetetracarboxylic acid Mixed-valence Magnetism The molecular self-assembly, crystal structure and functional property of coordination polymers containing multidentate ligands are of considerable interest to inorganic and material chemists [1] . The diversity in the structure and topology of coordination polymers is attributed to the selection of metal centers and organic ligands as well as reaction pathways. Much effort has been focused on the design and controlled synthesis of copper complexes due to their attractive magnetic properties [2] , mixed-valence oxidation-state pairs [3] , luminescence and novel structural features. Polycarboxylate complexes have received considerable attention in recent decade. Numerous complexes with polycarboxylate ligands, such as 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate, 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylate and 1,2,4,5-benzenetetracarboxylate, have been prepared and structurally characterized [4] . Recently, 1,2,4-triazole and its derivatives are of increasing interest in constructing coordination polymers. 2,6-Bis(1,2,4-triazolyl)pyridine ( Scheme 1 ) possesses seven nitrogen atoms, which is a potential valuable N-heterocyclic ligand. Three btp complexes have been documented up to date [5–7] . In the course of our investigation for coordination polymers, a ferromagnetic copper complex and a mixed-valence copper complex were prepared unexpected by combining polycarboxylate and btp with copper ion. Herein, we report their synthesis, crystal structures and thermal stabilities as well as magnetic property of 1 . Ligand btp was synthesized according to the literature method [8] . Complex 1 was prepared by hydrothermal reaction of Cu(NO 3 ) 2 · 3H 2 O (0.3 mmol), btp (0.2 mmol), H 3 btc (0.2 mmol) and NaOH (0.6 mmol) in 8 mL water at 140 °C for 3 days, afforded blue rhombic crystals in 60% yield based on btp. Elemental anal. calcd for C 18 H 13 Cu 2 N 7 O 8 (%): C 37.13, H 2.23, N 16.83; found: C 37.40, H 2.29, N 16.59. IR (KBr, cm −1 ): 3515 m, 3093w, 1615 s, 1583 m, 1514 m, 1379 s, 1348 s, 1046 m, 724 m. Complex 2 was prepared by hydrothermal reaction of Cu(NO 3 ) 2 · 3H 2 O (0.2 mmol), btp (0.1 mmol), H 4 btec (0.1 mmol) and NaOH (0.4 mmol) in 8 mL water at 140 °C for 3 days, afforded green block crystals in 40% yield based on btp. Elemental anal. calcd for C 19 H 12 Cu 2 N 7 O 9 (%): C 37.41, H 1.98, N 16.08; found: C 36.30, H 1.93, N 15.20. IR (KBr, cm −1 ): 3445 m, 3130 w, 1698 m, 1608 s, 1529 m, 1467 m, 1387 s, 1262 m, 1062 m, 634 m. X-ray structural analysis [9] revealed the complex 1 is a 3-D coordination polymer. As shown in Fig. 1 , the asymmetric unit contains two independent Cu(II) ions, btp ligand, btc 3− anion, OH − group and a coordinated H 2 O. Btp acts as a bidentate bridging ligand binds to Cu(II) ions using two triazole N-terminals with average Cu–N bond length of 2.006 Å. Other triazole N atoms and the pyridyl N atom are free. H 3 btc is completely deprotonated and acts as a tetradentate ligand bound to three Cu(II) ions. The Cu–O bond lengths vary from 1.917(2) to 1.971(2) Å. Cu(1) is five-coordinated, with a square–pyramidal geometry. The basal position is occupied by triazole N(1), hydroxyl O(1H), carboxyl O(1) and O(6A) with bond angle N(1)–Cu(1)–O(6A) 171.01(11)° and O(1)–Cu(1)–O(1H) 159.08(10)°. In the apical position, water molecule O(2W) is coordinated to Cu(1) with a distance of 2.514 Å. Hydroxyl O(1H) is tridentate. It bridges Cu(1) and Cu(2A) with bond lengths 1.917(2) and 1.934(2) Å, while coordinates weakly to Cu(2) with a distance 2.411(2) Å. Therefore Cu(2) is also square-pyramidal five-coordinated. The basal position is occupied by N(6A), O(3A), O(5B) and O(1HA) with N(6A)–Cu(2)–O(5B) 173.97(10)° and O(1HA)–Cu(2)–O(3A) 176.4(1)°. The apical position is occupied by O(1H) with a distance of 2.411(2) Å. Amongst three carboxylate groups of btc 3− , two carboxylates are monodentate and coordinate to Cu(1), Cu(2). A bidentate carboxylate and a OH − group are bound to Cu(1) and Cu(2A) to form a triply bridged dicopper unit (μ-OH)(μ-O 2 CR)Cu 2 with a Cu(1)⋯Cu(2A) separation of 3.2170(7) Å. The bond angle Cu(1)–O(1H)–Cu(2A) is 113.31(12)°. Two (μ-OH)(μ-O 2 CR)Cu 2 units are connected together by weak Cu(2)–O(1H) bond to form a tetranuclear structure with butterfly. Such Cu 4 aggregates are further linked by btp and btc 3− to form a 3-D polymeric framework. In addition, there exist some hydrogen-bonding interactions involving H 2 O, OH − with N(2), N(7), O(4) and O(5) atoms. Complex 2 is a 3-D coordination polymer. The asymmetric unit consists of two independent copper ions, Hbtec 3− anion, dtp ligand and a lattice H 2 O. As shown in Fig. 2 , Cu(1) is in a square four-coordinated environment and surrounded by triazole N(1) and three carboxyl O-donors from different Hbtec 3− . Cu(1)–N(1) bond length is 2.003(3) Å, and average Cu(1)–O bond length is 1.933 Å. Cu(2) is in a trigonal geometry surrounded by three triazole N-donors from three btp ligands. Average Cu(2)–N bond length is 2.003 Å. Interestingly, the complex is a Cu I /Cu II mixed-valence compound, although Cu II salt was used in the preparation reaction. Using the bond valence sum (BVS) analysis method [11] , we calculate the BVS value of Cu(1), which is 1.90 and consistent with a Cu 2+ oxidation state. The BVS value of Cu(2) is 1.00, which is exactly consistent with a Cu + oxidation state [12] . Although complex 2 contains Cu(I) ions, however it is quite stable in air. Unlike the structure of 1 , btp ligand is tetradentate in 2 , which coordinates to three Cu(I) and a Cu(II) through four triazole N-donors. The pyridyl plane has a dihedral angle of 22.36° with the triazole N(6)N(7)C(19)N(5)C(18) plane, while has a dihedral angle of 9.02° with another triazole plane. H 4 btec is partially deprotonated and formed a Hbtec 3− anion, which coordinates to three Cu(II) through three monodentate carboxylate groups. The carboxyl O(4) has H-bonding interaction with lattice water. Through Btp and Hbtec 3− multidentate bridging ligands, Cu(I) and Cu(II) ions are connected to form a 3-D metal-organic framework as shown in packing diagram. The thermogravimetric analysis measurements of 1 , 2 were performed in the temperature range of 20–800 °C in air. Complex 1 was a little efflorescent and lost lattice water slowly when the crystal sample kept at room temperature. The resulting powder sample of 1 was heated to 280 °C without weight change. A rapid weight-loss step occurred in the range 280–330 °C with a strong exothermic peak at 296.1 °C, indicated a mixed process of 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylate decomposed and bridging OH − groups dehydrated. This process might lead to an intermediate product [Cu 2 O(btp)(CO 3 )] (found 70.29%; calcd 73.76%) [13,14] . The intermediate decomposed further to form CuO residue at 800 °C (found 30.82%; calcd 28.19%). Complex 2 lost lattice water near 140 °C (found 1.14%; calcd 2.95%). The Hbtec 3− ligand decomposed rapidly in the range 280–310 °C (found 23.19%; calcd 21.51%), which might lead to the formation of intermediate product [Cu 2 (btp)(CO 3 ) 2 ] (found 75.67%; calcd 75.52%). The intermediate decomposed further to form CuO residue at high temperature. The magnetic susceptibilities of complex 1 were measured in the range 4–310 K on a Quantum Design PPMS-9 magnetometer at a magnetic field of 5000 Oe. Diamagnetic correction was made with Pascal’s constants. The variation of χ M and χ M T versus T for dicopper unit is plotted in Fig. 3 . By lowering the temperature from 310 to 4 K, the χ M T value increased continuously from 1.11 to 1.52 cm 3 K mol −1 . This result indicates the presence of ferromagnetic interaction between Cu(II) ions. Considering the dicopper cores isolated by larger dtp and btc 3− ligands, the appropriate magnetic exchange pathway in (μ-OH)(μ-O 2 CR)Cu 2 core is through the hydroxyl and bidentate carboxylate bridges. Due to the magnetic couple is located at dicopper unit. Bleaney–Bowers expression based on spin Hamiltonian ( H = −2 J S 1 · S 2 ) is employed to evaluated the magnetic exchange constant by fitting the magnetic susceptibility data [15] . This gives the singlet-triplet energy separation value 2 J = 21.30 cm −1 , g = 2.43, and an agreement factor R of 1.6 × 10 −4 . Most of carboxylato-bridging dinuclear Cu(II) complexes are antiferromagnetic couple, while the magnetic interactions of hydroxyl-bridging dicopper complexes strongly depend on the Cu–O–Cu angles [16] . A series of triply bridged dicopper(II) complexes containing carboxylate and hydroxyl bridges exhibit ferromagnetic couples where Cu(II) ions are square-pyramidal coordination and the Cu–O(H)–Cu angles are from 101 to 107° [17] . In complex 1 , the Cu–O(H)–Cu angle is 113.31(12)°, which shows a ferromagnetic interaction. The hydroxyl plays an important role in propagating magnetic exchange interaction between the Cu(II) ions. This phenomenon were also observed in several (μ-OH)(μ-O 2 CR)Cu 2 cores where the magnetic interactions primarily depend upon the Cu–O–Cu angle [18,19] . The complex 2 contains non-magnetic Cu(I) ion and paramagnetic Cu(II) ion which are isolated by large 1,2,4,5-benzenetetracarboxylate ligand. Its magnetic interaction should be weak and has not been further investigated. In conclusion, two novel copper coordination polymers have been assembled by polycarboxylate and 2,6-bis(1,2,4-triazolyl)pyridine ligands. They present interesting structures and properties, one is a ferromagnetic Cu II complex, and the other one is a Cu I /Cu II mixed-valence complex. 46icicIw.title: Convenient synthesis of perfluoroalkyl substituted 2-oxopyridine-fused 1,3-diazaheterocycles via a one-pot three-component reaction
46icicIw.abstract: An efficient one-pot synthesis of perfluoroalkylated ring-fused 2-pyridones by three-component reaction of diamine, ketene dithioacetal, and methyl 2-perfluoroalkynoate in EtOH is reported. This protocol has the advantages of easiness, higher yields, and shorter reaction time. A plausible mechanism for this type of cyclization is proposed. © 2013 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.

RB1elQ85.abstract: trans-2,3-Dihydrofuran derivatives 3 and trans-1,2-cyclopropane derivatives 4 were prepared with high chemoselectivity and moderate overall chemical yield by the reaction of α,β-unsaturated sulfones 1 with arsonium bromides 2 in the presence of potassium carbonate. orzWPimu.title: Convenient one-pot synthesis of fluorinated DHPs derivatives and their further transformations
orzWPimu.abstract: One-pot four-component reactions of aromatic aldehyde, Meldrum’s acid, ethyl-4,4,4-trifluoro-1,3-dioxobutanoate, and ammonium acetate afford ethyl 2-hydroxy-6-oxo-4-aryl-2-(trifluoromethyl)piperidine-3-carboxylate in good yields. The one-pot four-component process consists of an initial Michael addition, and a subsequent intramolecular cyclization. The effect of solvents on the reaction efficiency and yield is briefly investigated. The structure of product is further confirmed by XRD analysis. Meanwhile, the further transformation of hemi-aminal moiety to the corresponding dehydrated product is also achieved under the mild reaction conditions. The possible mechanism for the formation of product is presented.

i3NZyEDk.title: Synthesis, structures and thermal stabilities of three 1-D coordination polymers based on flexible polycarboxylates
i3NZyEDk.abstract: Three new coordination polymers, Cu(butca)0.5(bipy)(H 2O)]n 2nH2O (1), [Zn(H2butca) (phen)(H2O)]n nH2O (2), and Cd(H 2chhca)0.5(phen)(H2O)]n 2nH 2O (3) (H4butca =1,2,3,4-butanetetracarboxylic acid, H6chhca = 1,2,3,4,5,6-cyclohexanehexacarboxylic acid), were prepared and characterized by EA, IR, TG, and X-ray crystallography. Complex 1 is a 1-D double-chain coordination polymer in which tetradentate butca4- coordinates to four Cu(II) ions through four monodentate carboxylates. Complex 2 is a 1-D chain with tridentate H2butca2- coordinating to two Zn(II) ions through monodentate and chelating carboxylates. Complex 3 is a 1-D double-chain coordination polymer. H2chhca4- is octadentate coordinating to four Cd(II) ions through four chelating carboxylates. Hydrogen bonds and π-π stacking interactions play important roles in the formation of supramolecular architectures. The thermal stabilities of 1-3 show dehydrated coordination polymers are thermally stable in the range 260-400°C. © 2010 Taylor & Francis.

u0zfLgXB.title: Synthesis, structures and guest molecules adsorption of Zn(II)-bridged metal-organic polymers
u0zfLgXB.abstract: Two coordination polymers {[Zn(fum)(btmb)]·3H 2O} n (1) and {[Zn(2,3-pzdc)(tttmb)(H 2O) 2] ·H 2O} n (2) (H 2fum = fumaric acid, btmb = 4,4′-bis(1,2,4-triazol-1-ylmethyl)biphenyl, 2,3-H 2pzdc = 2,3-pyrazinedicarboxylic acid, tttmb = 1,3,5-tris(triazol-1-ylmethyl)-2,4,6- trimethylbenzene) have been synthesized and structurally characterized. Compound 1 is a two-fold interpenetrating 2D network; significant π-π interactions in adjacent layers finally result in a 3D supramolecular framework with 14.167 × 7.831 Å channel. Compound 2 is a 1D chain. The guest molecules (fluorescein and phenylfluorone) adsorption behaviors of 1 and luminescent properties of 1 and 2 have been investigated. © 2012 Published by Elsevier B.V.

RfY4l6pn.title: Synthesis, crystal structure and magnetic properties of two coordination polymers with 4-(4-carboxyphenyl)-4,2��:6��,4��-terpyridine ligand
RfY4l6pn.abstract: MnII and CoII salts reacting with 4-(4-carboxyphenyl)-4,2��:6��,4��-terpyridine (4-Hcptpy) in DMF/H2O afford two complexes, [Mn(4-cptpy)(DMF)(H2O) 2]n��n(4-cptpy)��nDMF (1) and [Co(4-cptpy)2(H2O)2]n (2). Complex 1 is a 1D ribbon coordination polymer assembled by Mn2 dimer and tridentate 4-cptpy ligand. The guest 4-cptpy anion is embedded in 3D supramolecular architecture with strong hydrogen bonds. Complex 2 is a 1D linear chain coordination polymer with quadrangled pores. The complex 1 releases H2O and DMF in 87-150 C, and the anhydrous [Mn(4-cptpy)] n��n(4-cptpy) remains thermally stable until 403 C. Variable temperature magnetic susceptibility study in 2-300 K proves that a weak antiferromagnetic interaction exists in the (��-O2CR) 2Mn2 core. ? 2014 Elsevier B.V.

d2GsStoL.title: Three-component synthesis of 2-amino-3-cyano-5-oxo-4-perfluoroalkyl-5,6,7, 8-tetrahydro-4H-chromene derivatives
d2GsStoL.abstract: A variety of 2-amino-3-cyano-5-oxo-4-perfluoroalkyl-5,6,7,8-tetrahydro-4H- chromene derivatives were achieved via a one-pot, three-component reaction from easily available methyl 2-perfluoroalkynoate, malononitrile (or ethyl cyanoacetate), and diverse cyclic 1,3-diketones. Moderate to good yields (up to 93%) were obtained in the presence of catalytic methylamine. This process went through a tandem Michael addition-cyclization reaction and was mild and easily performed. © 2013 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.

FhqwQvjy.title: A facile preparation of trans-1,2-cyclopropanes containing p-trifluoromethylphenyl group and its application to the construction of pyrazole and cyclopropane ring fused pyridazinone derivatives
FhqwQvjy.abstract: A facile methodology for the preparation of highly functionalized trans-1,2-cyclopropanes containing p-trifluoromethylphenyl group 3 is described. Arsonium bromides 1 reacted with electron-deficient olefins 2 in the presence of K2CO3 to provide 3 stereoselectively in moderate to good yields. This process has been successfully applied to the construction of cyclopropane ring fused pyridazinone derivatives 4 or pyrazole derivatives 5. © 2008 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.

dW1WDm66.title: Iodine catalyzed one-pot multi-component reaction to CF 3- containing spiro[indene-2,3′-piperidine] derivatives
dW1WDm66.abstract: In the presence of a catalytic amount of molecular iodine (0.1 equiv.), the one-pot multi-component reaction of ethyl trifluoroacetoacetate 1, indan-1,3-dione 2, ammonium acetate 3 and aromatic aldehyde 4 mainly gave the ethyl-6′-hydroxy-1,3-dioxo-2′,4′-diaryl-6′- (trifluoromethyl)-1,3-dihydrospiro[indene-2,3′-piperidine] -5′-carboxylate derivatives 5, along with the minor product 2-trifluoromethyl-2,3,4,5-tetrahydro-1H-indeno[1,2-b]pyridine derivatives 6. A plausible reaction mechanism for the formation of 5, 6 was presented. The structures of compounds 5, 6 were fully confirmed by 1H NMR, 19F NMR, MS, IR spectroscopies and elemental analysis or high resolution mass spectra (HRMS). Meanwhile, the representative 5a and 6h were further confirmed by XRD analysis. © 2011 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.

eMtQryHd.title: Poly[dinitrato[μ3-2,4,6-tris-(4-pyrid-yl)-1,3,5-triazine] cobalt(II)]
eMtQryHd.abstract: The solvothermal reaction of Co(NO3)2 and 2,4,6-tris(4-pyridyl)-1,3,5-triazine in dimethyl-formamide/ethanol mixed solvent afforded the title coordination polymer, [Co(NO3)2(C 18H12N6)]n, in which the Co II atom is seven-coordinated by pyridyl groups of three different ligands and two chelating nitrate anions. The complex displays a nano-sized porous metal-organic framework that belongs to a (10,3) topological network.

k9d7eTde.title: A convenient one-pot synthesis of 2-(trifluoromethyl)-3,4,7,8-tetrahydro-2H-chromen-5(6H)-one derivatives and their further transformations
k9d7eTde.abstract: The trifluoromethyl containing heterocycles, 2-hydroxy-4-aryl-3-(thien-2-oyl)-2-(trifluoromethyl)-3,4,7,8-tetrahydro-2H-chromen-5(6H)-one derivatives 4, were synthesized via a one-pot three-component reaction of aldehyde 1 with 1,3-cyclohexanedione 2 and 4,4,4-trifluoro-1-(thien-2-yl)butane-1,3-dione 3 in the presence of a catalytic amount of Et 3N. The effect of bases and solvents on the reaction efficiency and yield was briefly investigated. Treatment of 4 with an excess amount of NH 4OAc in ethanol afforded 2-trifluoromethyl-1H-quinolin-5-one derivatives 5. Refluxing of 4 with TsOH in CHCl 3 gave the corresponding dehydrated products 8. © 2008 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.

KIYuV2G9.title: Butane-1,2,3,4-tetra-carboxylic acid-4,4'-bipyridine (1/2).
KIYuV2G9.abstract: The hydro-thermal reaction of butane-1,2,3,4-tetra-carboxylic acid (H(4)butca), 4,4'-bipyridine (bipy) and Mn(SO(4))(2)·H(2)O afforded a new co-crystal, C(8)H(10)O(8)·2C(10)H(8)N(2) or H(4)butca·2(bipy), in which strong O-H⋯N hydrogen-bonding and weak π-π stacking [centroid-centroid distance = 3.8459 (19) Å] inter-actions assemble the organic mol-ecules into a three-dimensional supra-molecular framework. C-H⋯O inter-actions are also present. The whole mol-ecule has inversion symmetry.

e72xjRpj.title: Hydrothermal synthesis and crystal structure of a novel cyanide-bridged double helical copper(I) coordination polymer [Cu3(CN)3(phen)]n
e72xjRpj.abstract: Hydrothermal reaction of CuCN, K 3 [Fe(CN) 6 ] and 1,10-phenanthroline affords a novel cyanide-bridged copper(I) coordination polymer [Cu 3 (CN) 3 (phen)] n ( 1 ). The complex displays an interesting one-dimensional neutral double helical framework with (phen)Cu–CN– side-arms as interchain bridges. The double helical chains are close packed in a parallel fashion, and the phen ligands stack in an interpenetrating mode, which leads to π–π interactions between parallel phen planes. The thermal stability and fluorescent property have also been investigated.

xrSoSuCn.title: Solvothermal synthesis and diverse coordinate structures of a series of luminescent copper(I) thiocyanate coordination polymers based on N-heterocyclic ligands
xrSoSuCn.abstract: Solvothermal reactions of CuSCN with 4-amine-3,5-bis(3-pyridyl)-1,2,4- triazole (3-Abpt), 5-(4-pyridyl)tetrazole (4-Ptz), and 2-(n-pyridyl) benzimidazole (n-PyHBIm, n = 4, 3, 2) in acetonitrile afford six novel coordination polymers: [Cu5(SCN)5(3-Abpt) 2]n (1), [Cu(SCN)(3-Abpt)]n (2), [Cu(SCN)(4-Ptz)]n (3), [Cu2(SCN)2(4-PyHBIm)] n (4), [Cu2(SCN)2(3-PyHBIm)]n (5), and [Cu2(SCN)2(2-PyBIm)(2-PyHBIm)]n (6). All these complexes were structurally characterized by X-ray diffraction analysis. 1 is the first example of a 1,1,1,3-μ4-tetradentate thiocyanate complex which displays a three-dimensional (3D) polymeric framework constructed from thiocyanate and tetradentate 3-Abpt. 2 exhibits a two-dimensional (2D) 4.82 network constructed from unidentate thiocyanate and tridentate 3-Abpt. 3 is a one-dimensional (1D) ladder-like double-chain polymer assembled by bidentate thiocyanate and 4-Ptz ligands. 4 shows a 2D 1,1,3-μ3- thiocyanate copper 4.82 network where bidentate 4-PyHBIm locates at both sides of the 2D layer. 5 displays a 2D 63 network constructing from 1,3-μ3-thiocyanate and bidentate 3-PyHBIm. 6 is a ID 2 1 helical chain polymer constructing from 1,3-μ2- thiocyanate and 2-PyBIm anion. Bond valence sum (BVS) analysis and magnetic susceptibility indicate that 6 is a mixed-valence compound. The coordinate diversity of thiocyanate is discussed. 1-6 are all thermally stable up to 230-290 °C. They exhibit yellow or blue luminescence originating from ligandto-metal charge transfer or ligand-centered emission. © 2009 American Chemical Society.

zYltOSwQ.title: One-pot approach for the stereoselective synthesis of spirocyclopropyl oxindoles from isatins and arsonium salts
zYltOSwQ.abstract: A one-pot approach for highly stereoselective synthesis of spirocyclopropyl oxindoles 3 with good to excellent yields from the reaction of isatins 1 and arsonium salts 2 in the presence of K2CO3 is described. The structure of product 3 was confirmed by 1H NMR, 13C NMR, IR, MS, EA, and X-ray diffraction as well. © 2010 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.

zbdG1ujC.title: Synthesis, structure and adsorption of coordination polymers constructed from 3,3′,5,5′-azobenzenetetracarboxylic acid and Zn ions
zbdG1ujC.abstract: 3,3′,5,5′-Azobenzenetetracarboxylic acid (H4abtc) was synthesized by reduction of 5-nitroisophthalic acid in basic aqueous/ethanol solution in the presence of Zn powder. Three novel coordination polymers {[Zn2(η6-ao2btc)(η2-2, 2′-bpy)2(H2O)2]·2H 2O}1 n (1), {[Zn2(η8- aobtc)(η2-phen)(H2O)]·DMF}3 n (2), and {(Hap)2[Zn3(η9-aobtc) 2]·2H2O}3 n (3) (2,2′-bpy = 2,2′-bipyridine, phen = 1,10-phenanthroline, ap = 4-aminopyridine, ao2btc4- and aobtc4- are two oxidized forms of H4abtc ligand) were prepared under hydrothermal conditions. The structures of 1-3 were characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction. Complex 1 is a 1D chain polymer, while 2 and 3 are porous 3D metal-organic frameworks with a cavity size of 9 Å diameter and 7 × 15 Å rectangular cavities, respectively. In 1, ao2btc 4- links four mononuclear ZnO6 chromophores. Ligand aobtc4- in 2 links four dinuclear Zn2(CO2) 4(H2O)N2, while aobtc4- in 3 bridges four trinuclear Zn3(CO2)8. From a topology point of view, ao2btc4- or aobtc4- are all 4-connected linkers in 1-3, while the mononuclear ZnO6 in 1, dinuclear Zn2(CO2)4(H2O)N 2 in 2 and trinuclear Zn3(CO2)8 in 3 are 2, 4 and 8 connected nodes, respectively. Zn(ii) in complex 2 can be replaced by Cu(ii), Ni(ii) and Co(ii) with simultaneous loss of crystallinity. The metal ion exchange rate decrease in the order Co(ii) < Ni(ii) < Cu(ii). 2 can encapsulate iodine (I2) in cyclohexane solution to form 2⊃0.1I2. The encapsulated I2 can be released completely in ethanol. The Hap+ in 3 can be replaced by methylene blue in aqueous solution to form 3⊃0.1methylene blue. The insignificant replacement is an indication that the guest molecule in the cavity channel is immobile, which prevents further substitution. With a bis-oxo group in the azo moiety, the framework of 1 is so unstable that it will decompose at ∼150 °C with simultaneous release of NO. Complexes 2 and 3 are stable at 330 °C. IR and fluorescence spectra were also discussed. © 2013 The Royal Society of Chemistry.

OHI8NdES.title: Aqua(L-aspartato-k2N,O)(2,2′-bipyridine k 2N,N)copper(II) pentahydrate
OHI8NdES.abstract: In the title compound, [Cu(C4H5NO4)(C 10H8N2)(H2O)]·5H 2O, the CuII atom is coordinated by an N,O-bidentate l-aspartate dianion, a bipyridine ligand and a water molecule in a distorted square-pyramidal geometry. Intermolecular hydrogen bonds involving the non-coordinated water molecules help to consolidate the crystal packing. © 2006 International Union of Crystallography. All rights reserved.

UnLrq7Ir.title: A simple and convenient synthesis of 2-(perfluoroalkyl)-4H-chromenes from salicyl N-tosylimines or salicylaldehydes and methyl 2-perfluoroalkynoates
UnLrq7Ir.abstract: Et3N-catalyzed reactions of salicyl N-tosylimines or salicylaldehydes with methyl 2-perfluoroalkynoates proceed smoothly at room temperature in dichloromethane (DCM) or dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO) to give the corresponding fluorinated chromenes in good to excellent yields with high regioselectivity. © 2009 Elsevier Ltd. uLDZ1AzW.title: Novel MOFs with tetrahedral cavity assembled from 4,4′,4″-s- triazine-2,4,6-triyltribenzoic acid (H 3TATB)
uLDZ1AzW.abstract: Three novel 3D complexes {H 2[Zn 6(μ 4-O) (TATB) 4]} n (1), [Cd 3(TATB) 2] n (2), and [Mn 3(TATB) 2] n (3) were synthesized from 4,4′,4″-s-triazine-2,4,6-triyltribenzoic acid (H 3TATB) and corresponding metal salts under hydrothermal conditions. These complexes were characterized by elemental analyses, IR spectra, luminescent spectra, thermogravimetric analysis (TGA), and single crystal structure. Complex 1 adopted a straight Zn 4(μ 4-O) linked by TATB 3- subunit to form an adamantane structure with a fully empty tetrahedral cavity. Two naked protons floated in the complex. This structure supports the existence of naked protons in nature. In complexes 2-3, the six deprotonated carboxylic oxygen of TATB 3- coordinated to eight metal ions to form a 3D close-packed structure. Its density of 1.837 mg m -3 made complex 2 one of the most closely packed structure based on H 3TATB ever determined. Coordination polyhedral linked each other to form a diamondoid metal-oxygen framework in 2 and 3. All the coordination polymers were thermally stable up to 470°C. These were the most thermally stable coordination polymers. A high-resolution transmission electron microscope indicated that the metal oxide is porous with pore diameters of ∼ 2 nm. © 2011 Elsevier B.V.

BtdPQNUW.title: Anion effects on the formation of silver(I) complexes with the flexible ligand 4,4′-Bis(1,2,4-triazol-1-ylmethyl)biphenyl
BtdPQNUW.abstract: The reaction of 4,4′-bis(1,2,4-triazol-1-ylmethyl)biphenyl (btmb) with silver(I) salts of BF 4 -, NO 3 - and N 3 - led to the formation of four new silver(I) coordination polymers {[Ag(btmb)]BF 4} n (1), {[Ag 2(btmb) 3](NO 3) 2(H 2O) 5} n (2), [Ag 2(btmb)(N 3) 2] n (3), and [Ag(btmb)(N 3)] n (4). Their coordination number varies from 2 (in 1) to 3 (in 2), 4 (in 3), and 5 (in 4). Different from the single chain structure of 1, complex 2 displays a 1D ladder-like double chain framework, whereas complex 3 exhibits a 2D layered architecture. Complex 4 has the same anion as complex 3 but shows a different metal-to-ligand ratio and a 1D double-zigzag chain structure. Both 3 and 4 have Ag⋯Ag argentophilic interactions. The ligand btmb adopts both cis or trans configuration in the studied complexes. A trans- or cis-btmb ligand link silver ions with Ag⋯Ag distances of ≈18 and 13 Å, respectively. BF 4 - and NO 3 - are non-coordinating anions in 1 and 2. N 3 - is the bridging anion in 3 (1,3-bridging fashion) and 4 (1,1-bridging fashion). These findings suggest that the coordination numbers around the Ag I ion correlate to the coordination abilities of anions and the btmb to silver ratio. In addition, the influence of anions on thermal stability were also investigated. This work is a good example that nicely supports the less explored field of anion-dependent structures of complexes with non-pyridyl ligands. © 2011 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim.

XKh8Ratg.title: Supramolecular networks constructed by mono-, bi- and polynuclear complexes incorporating uncoordinated 1,10-phenanthroline and water clusters
XKh8Ratg.abstract: Three supramolecular compounds, [Mn 2(chda)(phen) 4(H 2O)]·(ClO 4) 2·phen·4H 2O (1), [Cu(mal)(bipy)] n·2nH 2O (2) and [Cu(ca) 2(bipy)]·2H 2O (3) (chda = 1,1-cyclohexanediacetate, mal = maleate, Hca = cyanuric acid, bipy = 2,2′-bipyridine), have been synthesized and characterized by elemental analyses, IR spectra, thermal analyses and X-ray structural analyses. Compound 1 is a carboxylate-bridging binuclear complex incorporating uncoordinated 1,10-phenanthroline bonded by hydrogen bonding and π-π stacking interactions. Compound 2 is a 1D zigzag chain carboxylate coordination polymer incorporating cyclic (H 2O) 4 tetramers of lattice water, which further connect the zigzag chains through strong hydrogen bonds to form 2D supramolecular network. Compound 3 is a mononuclear complex in which H-bonding (H 2O) 8 water clusters further combine the complex through hydrogen bonds to form supramolecular framework. Thermal stabilities of 1 and 3 have also been investigated. © 2007 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.

PtAR6E76.title: Synthesis, crystal structures and selective oxygenation of dinuclear copper(II) complexes of N,N,N′,N′-xylylenediamine tetraacetate
PtAR6E76.abstract: Two dinuclear copper(II) complexes, [Cu 2 L1(imH) 2 (H 2 O) 2 ] · 4H 2 O ( 1 ) and [Cu 2 L2(imH) 2 (H 2 O) 2 ] · 2H 2 O ( 2 ) (L1H 4 = N , N , N ′, N ′- m -xylylenediamine tetraacetic acid, L2H 4 = N , N , N ′, N ′- p -xylylenediamine tetraacetic acid, imH = imidazole), were synthesized aiming at exploring the geometry of the flexible ligands on their complex structures and reactions with H 2 O 2 . In complex 1 , both Cu(II) ions are five-coordinated with square-pyramidal geometry and water molecules occupy the apical position. The Cu···Cu distance is 5.344(7) Å. Complex 2 adopts the same coordination geometry as that in 1 . The Cu···Cu distance is 7.812(5) Å. Complex 1 exhibits hydroxylation of the xylyl linker of the supporting ligand in the presence of H 2 O 2 in aqueous solution. No observable reaction took place under the identical conditions for complex 2 . Proximity effect of the metal center is responsible for the hydroxylation. Keywords Copper Polycarboxylate Imidazole H 2 O 2 Hydroxylation Supramolecular chemistry based on transition metals and multifunctional organic ligands currently have received considerable interests owing to their novel structural topologies and potential applications in host–guest chemistry, catalysis and magnetic materials [1] . Apart from the fundamental metal–ligand coordination covalent bond, the hydrogen bond is the most familiar organizing force in supramolecular assembly due to its moderately directional intermolecular interaction that may control short-range packing [2] . Multidentate carboxylate ligands can act as hydrogen-bond acceptors and hydrogen-bond donors, which make them good candidates to construct supramolecular networks. Although a number of supramolecular complexes have been obtained via self-assembly of the metal ions and rigid aromatic polycarboxylate ligands such as 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid, 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid and 1,2,4,5-benzenetetracarboxylic acid [3–4] . The investigation on supramolecular frameworks constructed from the flexible polycarboxylate ligands containing aromatic ring are rare and the effect of geometry of the ligands on the structure and reactivity remains unexplored. Keeping in mind the aforementioned points, two new flexible polycarboxylate ligands were designed and synthesized ( Scheme 1 ), in which the m -xylene and p -xylene were utilized to link two flexible iminodiacetic groups. On the other hand, dioxygen activation is a very hot topic in current chemistry research [5] . Dinuclear copper complexes are often served as bioinorganic model compounds to mimic metalloprotein such as hemocyanin and tyrosinase that activate dioxygen. For instance, Karlin and co-works have first demonstrated that the copper(I) complex, [Cu 2 ( m -XYLpy 2 )](PF 6 ) 2 ( m -XYLpy 2 = N , N , N ′, N ′-tetra-(2-pyridylethyl)- m -xylylene diamine) is capable of performing hydroxylation of the xylyl linkers of the supporting ligands in the presence of dioxygen [6] . Imidazole group also plays important roles in biological systems and copper–imidazole bonding is widely known in biological systems [7] . Otherwise, copper(II) complexes with imidazole ligands have recently also been reported to achieve highly ordered supramolecular assemblies [8–9] . Thus, in this work, two dinuclear copper(II) complexes, [Cu 2 L1(imH) 2 (H 2 O) 2 ] · 4H 2 O ( 1 ) and [Cu 2 L2(imH) 2 (H 2 O) 2 ] · 2H 2 O ( 2 ) (L1H 4 = N , N , N ′, N ′- m -xylylenediamine tetraacetic acid, L2H 4 = N , N , N ′, N ′- p -xylylenediamine tetraacetic acid, imH = imidazole) have been prepared and characterized by single crystal X-ray diffraction, IR, element analysis and thermogravimetric analysis (TGA). The reaction of copper(II) complexes with hydrogen peroxide (H 2 O 2 ) have also been studied by UV–vis spectra. The flexible chelating ligands L1H 4 and L2H 4 were prepared following a reported procedure for synthesizing 1,3,5-benzenemethyltriiminodiacetic acid [10,11] . Complexes 1 and 2 were achieved by reaction of the ligand L1H 4 or L2H 4 and imidazole with copper nitrate hexahydrate in the molar ratio of 1:2:2 in aqueous solution, respectively [12] . The detailed description of the IR spectra and thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) results of 1 and 2 see the supporting information . Due to the presence of methylene groups between the central benzene ring and terminal iminodiacetic group in L1H 4 and L2H 4 , there can be two conformations when they coordinate with metal ions, namely, cis , cis -conformation ( V -form) and trans , trans -conformation ( Z -form) ( Chart S1 ). Crystallographic analysis reveals that the two iminodiacetate groups in complex 1 and 2 are all in opposite directions to the central benzene ring ( Fig. 1 ). Therefore, the conformations of the resulting complex 1 and 2 are in Z -form. Complex 1 crystallizes in space group P −1 and there is a neutral dinuclear copper(II) complex and four guest water molecules in the crystallographic asymmetric unit [13] . As shown in Fig. 1 a, each Cu(II) ion in 1 has a N 2 O 3 coordination environment that can be described as distorted square-pyramidal geometry (type 4 + 1, τ = 0.05) according to the Addison–Reedijk geometric criterion [14] . The basal plane defined by one nitrogen atom from imidazole and one nitrogen atom and two oxygen atoms from iminodiacetate group. The Cu–O distance range from 1.950(3) to 1.966(3) Å. Bond lengths of Cu–N(imidazole) and Cu–N(iminodiacetate) are 1.950(3) and 2.009(3) Å, respectively. These bond lengths are comparable to those reported values [15] . Water molecules occupied the apical position with a longer distances of 2.319 Å (Cu1–O1W) and 2.334 Å (Cu2–O2W). The Cu1···Cu2 separation is 5.344 Å. Each iminodiacetate group coordinates to Cu1 or Cu2 ion in mer -NO2 tridentate chelating mode, which led to the formation of two five-member rings of CuNC 2 O with a dihedral angle of 14° for Cu1 and 15° for Cu2. The two imidazolyl rings are on the opposite side of the benzene plane and inclined to the phenyl ring at angles of 61.4° for Cu1 and 60.3° for Cu2, while the dihedral angle of the two imidazole plane is 73.5°, which indicates that they fall nearly perpendicular to each other. Complex 2 crystallizes in space group P 2(1)/ n and features a dinuclear single-stranded helical arrangement ( Fig. 1 b) similar to the pentanuclear helicate reported by Pan et al. [16] , which possesses an inversion center with only half of the atoms being crystallographically independent. The Cu(II) center in 2 has the same N 2 O 3 coordination environment with that in 1 described as slightly distorted square-pyramidal ( τ = 0.08) geometry. Accordingly, the iminodiacetate group gives two nearly coplanar five-membered chelated ring of CuNC 2 O with a dihedral angle of 13.5°, and the Cu–N(imidazole) distance is 1.952(2) Å and Cu–N(iminodiacetate group) distance is 2.009(2) Å, which also agreed well with the reported values [15] . The other bond lengths are slightly different from complex 1 , particularly the distance of Cu1–O1 and Cu1–O3 bond in basal plane are 1.972(2) Å and 1.979(2) Å, which are longer than that of 1 , while the apical Cu1–O1W bond has a shorter distance with 2.259 Å compared to 2.319 or 2.334 Å in 1 . The Cu···Cu distance in 2 is 7.812 Å, which is much longer than that in 1 . Again, the two imidazolyl rings in 2 are on the opposite side of the benzene plane, but different from 1 , the two imidazole planes are not only parallel to each other but also almost parallel to the phenyl ring with the dihedral angle of 16.9°. Analysis of the crystal packing of the complex 1 shows that the basic building units [Cu 2 L1(imH) 2 (H 2 O) 2 ] are connected into a one-dimensional tube-like polymeric chain running parallel to the a direction by the weak C–H···O hydrogen-bond interactions [17] (C10–H10···O6, C21–H21···O8) ( Fig S1a ). One-dimensional tube-like chains are further linked into a three-dimensional structure through the O(W)–H···O hydrogen-bonding interactions in b direction and the N–H···O hydrogen-bonding interactions in c direction ( Fig. S2 ). Complex 2 stacked into a one-dimensional helical structure by the N–H···O hydrogen-bonding interactions ( Fig. S1b ), and the one-dimensional helical chains further assembly into 2D layer supramolecular framework through O(W)–H···O hydrogen-bonding interactions ( Fig. S3 ). A structural comparison of compound 1 and 2 suggests that the delicate difference of the geometry of ligands L1H 4 and L2H 4 can led to remarkable differences in the crystal packing of their copper(II) complexes. It is reported that the diiron(III) complex of L1 4− could hydroxylate the xylyl linker in the presence of H 2 O 2 [18] . Whether copper(II) complex of this ligand can do the same work is not clear. Some other copper(I) complexes with similar structure (pyridine or pyrazole instead of carboxylate) can activate dioxygen and hydrolylate the supporting ligands in organic solvents [6,19] , which stimulated us to investigate the reactions of complex 1 and 2 with H 2 O 2 by UV–vis spectra. As can be seen from Fig. 2 , the electronic absorption spectra of complex 1 and 2 are very similar due to the fact that they have almost the same chromophores, both exhibit a weak absorption feature at ∼650 nm ( ε < 100) which was attributed to the d – d transition of the copper(II) center. Addition of 80 equiv of H 2 O 2 into the blue aqueous solution of complex 1 at room temperature resulted in a rapid color change from blue to yellow. Meanwhile, a new absorption band appeared at ∼380 nm ( ε = 2500) and the reaction quickly proceeds and no detectable intermediate is observed at present stage. Although all attempts to crystallize this oxidized species was in vain so far, we can assign that the oxidized product is the hydroxylation of the xylyl linker in L1 4− by complex 1 /H 2 O 2 system ( Scheme 2 ) similar to its iron(II) complex [19] according to the similarity of 380 nm absorption to that of the phenol–copper(II) complex in both wavelength and absorption coefficient [20] . Additionally, the negative ion ESI-TOF/MS spectrum of the aqueous solution of 1 by addition of 80 equiv H 2 O 2 show a signal at m /z 641.0 attributable to the hydroxylated specie [Cu 2 (L1–O)(imH) 2 ] − , and its isotopic distribution patterns are almost identical to the corresponding simulated ones given by Isopro 3.0 ( Fig. S4) . Contrarily, there was no observable electronic spectral change for complex 2 under the same conditions. The significant difference of the reaction with H 2 O 2 by complex 1 and 2 can be explained from their crystal structures. In complex 1 , the distances of the Cu1 and Cu2 ions and the hydroxylated carbon atom (C2) of the xylyl linker in L1 are 3.070(6) and 3.114(5) Å, respectively, and the distance of dicopper core and the C2 atom is 1.557 Å. These distances are close to ensure hydroxylation take place. However the Cu···Cu distance in complex 2 is 7.812 Å and the central benzene ring of L2 4− lies in the center of the two copper centers, which disfavor the formation of a reactive oxygen intermediate for the hydroxylation. Thus, the selective hydroxylation occurred at the 2-position of the xylyl linker in ligand appears to be mostly due to the proximity effect of the metal center ( meta - or para -position). In summary, we have designed and synthesized two new flexible dinuclear copper complexes in which the two coordination metal centers situate the meta - or para -position, respectively. The copper(II) ions in both complexes adopt a distort square-pyramidal geometry. The X-ray structural analysis clearly show that the delicate difference of the geometry of ligands can led to remarkable differences in the crystal packing of their copper(II) complexes. The present study offers important insights into geometric effects of ligands on the structure of supramolecular networks. Additionally, complex 1 may hydroxylate the xylyl linker in the ligand by reaction with H 2 O 2 while no ligand hydroxylation take place for complex 2 , and the proximity effect of the metal center seems to be responsible for the hydroxylation. ffMRYGgD.title: Copper(I)-catalyzed coupling cyclization of methyl perfluoroalk-2-ynoates with 2-aminobenzonitriles: Synthesis of 2-perfluoroalkylated quinolines
ffMRYGgD.abstract: An efficient route to 2-perfluoroalkylated quinoline derivatives through the copper(I)-mediated coupling-cyclization of 2-aminobenzonitriles with methyl perfluoroalk-2-ynoates is described. Moderate to excellent yields have been achieved under mild conditions. The reaction mechanism is also discussed. Copyright © 2013 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim.
