U0FX6WEU.title: Synthesis, structures and thermal stabilities of five copper(II) coordination polymers based on 2,4,6-tris(pyridyl)-1,3,5-triazine and 1,2,4,5-benzenetetracarboxylate ligands

jzF582xy.title: Syntheses, topological networks and properties of four complexes based on 4-amino-3,5-bis(3-pyridyl)-1,2,4-triazole ligand
jzF582xy.abstract: Reactions of metal acetates with 4-amino-3,5-bis(3-pyridyl)-1,2,4-triazole (3-abpt) and co-ligands gave rise to four new complexes, namely [Zn 2 (3-abpt)(beta)(DMF) (H 2 O) 2 ] n · n H 2 O ( 1 ), [Zn(3-abpt)(ip)] n ·3 n H 2 O ( 2 ), [Zn(3-abpt)(ip)(H 2 O) 2 ] n ·2 n H 2 O ( 3 ), and [Cu 2 (3-abpt) 2 (C 6 H 5 COO) 4 (H 2 O) 2 ] n ·2 n H 2 O ( 4 ) (ip = isophthalate, beta = 1,2,4,5-benzenetetracarboxylate). Compound 1 is a 3D coordination polymer with uncommon 3,4-connected (6 2 .8) 2 (6 2 .8 2 .10 2 ) network. Compounds 2 – 4 are all 1D coordination polymers, which exhibit diversity structures. Compound 2 is a tubular-like chain, 3 is a ring-like network, and 4 is a zigzag chain. Their thermal stabilities and the photoluminescence of 1 have also been investigated. Keywords 4-Amino-3,5-bis(3-pyridyl)-1,2,4-triazole Coordination polymer Crystal structure Thermal analysis 1 Introduction Considerable attention has been paid to the study of metal coordination polymers because of their intriguing structural architectures and potential applications as functional materials [1–6] . However, it is still a challenging task to explore successful synthetic strategies for the preparation of coordination polymers with predictable structures and applications. Their preparations are highly influenced by reaction conditions such as pH value, solvent system, and temperature [7,8] . N-heterocyclic and polycarboxylate species have been extensively explored to obtain a series of materials due to their rich coordination mode. Currently, triazole ligands and their derivatives, known for their versatile coordination ability and wide applications as multidentate bridging ligands, are of considerable interest in constructing coordination polymers [9–13] . 4-Amino-3,5-bis(3-pyridyl)-1,2,4-triazole (3-abpt), an angular bridging ligand, can serve as a good candidate for the construction of molecular cages, rings, grids, and ladders [14–26] . While polycarboxylic acids also present a high structural effect in assembling coordination polymers due to their diverse binding modes [27–31] . On the other hand, with the aid of special intermolecular contacts, hydrogen bonding, and aromatic stacking force might play important roles in molecular recognition and assembly [32,33] . To illustrate these effects on the construction of supramolecular assembly, in the contribution, we will present four new complexes, namely [Zn 2 (3-abpt)(beta)(DMF)(H 2 O) 2 ] n · n H 2 O ( 1 ), [Zn(3-abpt)(ip)] n ·3 n H 2 O ( 2 ), [Zn(3-abpt)(ip)(H 2 O) 2 ] n ·2 n H 2 O ( 3 ), and [Cu 2 (3-abpt) 2 (C 6 H 5 COO) 4 (H 2 O) 2 ] n ·2 n H 2 O ( 4 ) (ip = isophthalate, beta = 1,2,4,5-benzenetetracarboxylate). We can find their structural discrepancy is dependent on many factors, such as subtle interplay of metal coordination preferences, ligand type, spatial extension, and steric constraints. Besides, hydrogen bonding and aromatic stacking force also play important roles in the formation of these polymeric materials. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials and methods The ligand 4-amino-3,5-bis(3-pyridyl)-1,2,4-triazole was prepared according to the literature method [34] . Other chemicals were of reagent grade and used as purchased without further purification. Elemental analyses (EA) were performed on a Vario EL III analyzer. Infrared spectra (IR) were recorded with a Nicolet A370 FT-IR spectrometer by KBr pellets in the range 400–4000 cm −1 . Thermogravimetric analyses (TG-DSC) were completed on a Netzsch STA 449C thermal analyzer at a heating rate of 10 °C/min in air. The fluorescent data were collected on an Edinburgh FL-FS920 TCSPC system. 2.2 Synthesis 2.2.1 [Zn 2 (3-abpt)(beta)(DMF)(H 2 O) 2 ] n · n H 2 O ( 1 ) An aqueous (5 mL) solution of Zn(OAc) 2 ·2H 2 O (0.024 g, 0.11 mmol) was mixed with a solution of 3-abpt (0.024 g, 0.10 mmol) in methanol (10 mL) with stirring. Then a solution of H 4 beta (0.013 g, 0.05 mmol) in H 2 O/DMF (5 mL/5 mL) was added into above mixture with continuous stirring for 30 min and filtered. The filtrate was left to stand at room temperature. Colorless block crystals of 1 suitable for X-ray analyses were produced by slow evaporation of the solvent after one week in a 20% yield (0.0147 g, based on 3-abpt). Anal . Calc. for C 25 H 25 Zn 2 N 7 O 12 : C, 40.24; H, 3.38; N, 13.14. Found: C, 39.15; H, 3.40; N, 12.53%. IR (KBr pellet, cm −1 ): 3382s, 3181s, 1656s, 1564vs, 1489m, 1419s, 1367vs, 1314m, 1132w, 873w, 813w, 765w, 701w, 685w, 583w. 2.2.2 [Zn(3-abpt)(ip)] n ·3 n H 2 O ( 2 ) A mixture of Zn(OAc) 2 ·2H 2 O (0.044 g, 0.20 mmol), 3-abpt (0.024 g, 0.10 mmol), H 2 ip (0.017 g, 0.10 mmol), and water (12 mL) was sealed in a Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel (15 mL). The mixture was heated at 140 °C for 5 days and then cooled to room temperature at a rate of 10 °C/h. Yellow quadrate crystals of 2 were collected in 23% yield (0.012 g, based on 3-abpt). Anal . Calc. for C 20 H 20 ZnN 6 O 7 : C, 46.04; H, 3.86; N, 16.11. Found: C, 46.52; H, 3.70; N, 16.29%. IR (KBr pellet, cm −1 ): 3350s, 1614vs, 1571m, 1549m, 1481m, 1450w, 1420m, 1383s, 1205w, 1041m, 828m, 733s, 695m, 654w, 569w, 437w. 2.2.3 Zn(3-abpt)(ip)(H 2 O) 2 ] n ·2 n H 2 O ( 3 ) A mixture of Zn(OAc) 2 ·2H 2 O (0.026 g, 0.12 mmol), 3-abpt (0.024 g, 0.10 mmol), H 2 ip (0.017 g, 0.10 mmol), and water (10 mL) was sealed in a Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel (15 mL). The mixture was heated at 140 °C for 3 days and then cooled to room temperature at a rate of 10 °C/h. A clear pink solution was obtained, which was left to stand for three days at room temperature. Pink prism crystals of 3 were collected in 24% yield (0.013 g, based on 3-abpt). Anal . Calc. for C 20 H 22 ZnN 6 O 8 : C, 44.50; H, 4.11; N, 15.57. Found: C, 44.31; H, 4.09; N, 15.50%. IR (KBr pellet, cm −1 ): 3353s, 3143s, 1670w, 1599s, 1546vs, 1480m, 1422s, 1373vs, 819w, 761m, 705s. 2.2.4 [Cu 2 (3-abpt) 2 (C 6 H 5 COO) 4 (HO 2 ) 2 ] n ·2 n H 2 O ( 4 ) An aqueous solution (5 mL) of Cu(OAc) 2 ·2H 2 O (0.024 g, 0.12 mmol) was mixed with a solution of 3-abpt (0.024 g, 0.10 mmol) and benzoic acid (0.024 g, 0.20 mmol) in methanol (5 mL) with stirring for 30 min and filtered. The filtrate was left to stand at room temperature. Blue block crystals of 4 suitable for X-ray analyses were produced by slow evaporation of the solvent after one week in a 25% yield (0.015 g, based on 3-abpt). Anal . Calc. for C 52 H 48 Cu 2 N 12 O 12 : C, 53.01; H, 4.28; N, 14.27. Found: C, 53.88; H, 4.18; N, 14.51%. IR (KBr pellet, cm −1 ): 3424m, 3342w, 3060w, 1599s, 1558s, 1486w, 1448w, 1383vs, 1129w, 982w, 848w, 817w, 721s, 691m, 653w. 2.3 X-ray crystallography Single crystal XRD data for compounds 1 – 4 were collected on a Bruker Smart Apex-II CCD diffractometer with graphite monochromatic Mo Kα radiation ( λ = 0.71073 Å) at room temperature. Empirical absorption corrections were applied using sadabs program. The structures were solved by direct methods with shelxs -97 program and refined by full-matrix least-squares on F 2 with shelxl -97 program [35] . All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically, and hydrogen atoms were located and included at their calculated positions. The crystal data and structure refinement results are summarized in Table 1 . Selected bond lengths and angles are listed in Table 2 . 3 Results and discussions 3.1 Structural description of [Zn 2 (3-abpt)(beta)(DMF)(H 2 O) 2 ] n · n H 2 O ( 1 ) Compound 1 is a three-dimensional (3D) coordination polymer based on 3-abpt and H 4 beta. There are two independent Zn(II) ions in the asymmetric unit. As shown in Fig. S1 , Zn1 center is octahedrally coordinated by one pyridyl nitrogen donor of 3-abpt and three oxygen atoms from one chelating and one monodentate carboxylate groups in the equatorial plane, and two oxygen atoms from coordinated water molecules at the axis positions with O1–Zn1–O2 angle of 171.8(2)°. With respect to Zn2, the distorted tetrahedral sphere is provided by one pyridyl nitrogen from 3-abpt, two oxygen atoms from different beta 4− anions in monodentate mode, and one oxygen donor from DMF molecule. The beta ligand acts as a μ 4 -bridge to link four metal ions, but present different coordination modes with Zn1 and Zn2 centers. The carboxylate groups in opposite position from beta 4− ligands adopt chelate and monodentate bridging modes to link Zn1 centers to form a 2D layer with Zn1 ⋯ Zn1 distance of 6.084 and 9.259 Å ( Fig. S2a ), while only adopt monodentate bridging mode as tetradentate ligand to link Zn2 centers to form the same 2D (4,4) network with Zn2 ⋯ Zn2 distance of 5.853 and 9.339 Å ( Fig. S2b ). In 1 , 3-abpt ligand acts as bidentate ligand in cis -fashion bridging Zn1 and Zn2 atoms ( Scheme S1 ). As shown in Fig. 1 a, the beta-Zn1 and beta-Zn2 layers are further connected by 3-abpt ligand to generate a 3D structure. Exclude the solvent molecule, a computation of voids by using the platon program [36] suggests a value of 223.6 Å 3 , corresponding to 7.8% of the unit-cell volume. In addition, some intra- and inter-molecular hydrogen bonds including O1–H1B ⋯ N3 (− x + 1, − y + 2, − z + 1), O1–H1C ⋯ O6 ( x , − y + 5/2, z + 1/2), O2–H2B ⋯ O4, O2–H2B ⋯ O3, O1W–H1WA ⋯ O3 (− x + 1, y + 1/2, − z + 1/2), O1W–H1WB ⋯ N2 ( x , − y + 5/2, z − 1/2), and some aromatic stacking interactions further stabilize its structure. Within the framework, the pyridyl ring N6 ∼ C5 of 3-abpt ligand is parallel to the phenyl ring C14 ∼ C16a of beta at ( x , 1/2 + y , 1/2 − z ), and the perpendicular distance between the two ring planes is 3.171(2) Å, with the distance between ring centroids is 3.818(3) Å. From the viewpoint of network topology, the complex 1 can be simplified as a 3,4 two-nodal net as shown in Fig. 1 b. The beta ligands can be treated as a 4-connected node, then, the Zn1 and Zn2 centers become 3-connected node. The Schafli symbol for this 3,4-connected uniform network is (6 2 .8) 2 (6 2 .8 2 .10 2 ) [37] , while the long vertex symbol is [6.6.8 2 ] [6.6.8.8.10 2 .10 2 ]. Comparing with reported 3,4-connected examples [38] , we find two cases that contain 6 2 .8 net, namely hst and tfi nets. However, hst and tfi nets are characterized by six- and eight-membered rings whereas the present one features six-, eight-, and ten-membered rings. Then, it is clear that the present case is different from the reported cases and presents a new type of 3,4-connected topology, but has been theoretically known as a derived net from the 4,4-connected bbf net by following the approach described by Blatov [39] . 3.2 Structural description of [Zn(3-abpt)(ip)] n ·3 n H 2 O ( 2 ) Compound 2 is a 1D tubular-like chain structure, in which Zn(II) centers are interlinked by ip 2− and 3-abpt ligands. Each Zn(II) atom is in a disordered tetrahedral coordination environment, surrounded by two pyridyl nitrogen atoms from different 3-abpt ligands and two oxygen atoms from monodentate bridging carboxylate groups of two ip ligands. The zinc atom is also weakly coordinated by the additional oxygen atoms of the carboxylate groups (drawn as fragmented bonds in Fig. S3 ). They are 2.561(3) Å from the zinc atom, which is significantly less than the sum of the van der Waals radii of 2.91 Å [40] . Two 3-abpt ligands take the cis -fashion to connect two Zn(II) atoms to get a {Zn 2 (3-abpt) 2 } bimetallic ring with a Zn ⋯ Zn distances of 10.347(2) Å. These units are further linked by ip bridge to afford a tubular-like chain ( Fig. 2 a), in which Zn ⋯ Zn separation by ip ligands is 10.152(3) Å. In addition, the hydrogen bonds like O3W–H3C ⋯ N2 (3− x , −1 − y , 1 − z ) between 1D tubular-like chains and some aromatic stacking interactions further connect these chains into a 3D network. There exists the interchain π–π stacking interaction between two phenyl rings of ip, with perpendicular and centroid-to-centroid distance of 3.554(2) Å and 3.889(4) Å, as shown in Fig. 2 b. 3.3 Structural description of [Zn(3-abpt)(ip)(H 2 O) 2 ] n ·2 n H 2 O ( 3 ) Compound 3 features a 1D ring-like infinite chain coordination structure in which Zn(II) centers are interlinked by ip and 3-abpt bridges. As shown in Fig. S4 , each Zn(II) atom is surrounded by two oxygen donors from different ip, two pyridyl nitrogen atoms from a pair of 3-abpt in cis -arrangement, and two oxygen atoms from coordinated water molecules to display a octahedral coordination geometry. As shown in Fig. 3 a, the Zn(II) centers are bridged by ip and 3-abpt ligands to yield a 1D ring-like chain with Zn ⋯ Zn separation of 9.8539(9) Å. The dihedral angle between the C(1) ∼ N(1) and C(8) ∼ N(6) planes in 3-abpt ligand is 29.74(1)°, showing some distortion. These polymeric chains are further linked through interchain O6–H6A ⋯ O4 (− x + 2, − y + 1, − z + 1) and O5–H5C ⋯ O4 (− x + 3/2, y − 1/2, − z + 1/2) interactions to form 2D layer. Furthermore, these layers connect by hydrogen bonds between lattice water molecules and carboxylate groups to generate a 3D architecture ( Fig. 3 b). 3.4 Structural description of [Cu 2 (3-abpt) 2 (C 6 H 5 COO) 4 (HO 2 ) 2 ] n ·2 n H 2 O ( 4 ) Compound 4 shows 1D zigzag chain structure. As shown in Fig. S5 , Cu1 shows a disordered octahedral sphere, coordinated by two pyridyl nitrogen atoms from different 3-abpt ligands, four carboxylate oxygen donors from two benzoic acids in chelate coordination mode. It should be pointed out that the distance of Cu1–O2 (2.566(2) Å) is longer than Cu1–O1 (1.957(2) Å). So we can conclude that the latter one have stronger coordination ability with Cu than the former one. Besides, weak coordination nature could be assigned to the former bond [41] . Cu2 is coordinated by two pyridyl nitrogen atoms from distinct 3-abpt molecules, two carboxylate oxygen atoms from different benzoic acids in unidentate mode, and two oxygen atoms from two water molecules in octahedral geometry. Similarity, Cu2–O5 (2.530(3) Å) is longer than Cu2–O3 (1.957(2) Å), suggesting its weak coordination. The bidentate 3-abpt ligands with cis -fashion link the Cu centers to furnish a zigzag chain with Cu ⋯ Cu distances of 9.4014(9) Å, as shown in Fig. 4 a. Furthermore, these adjacent chains are linked by hydrogen bonds such as O(1W)–H(1D) ⋯ O(2), O(1W)–H(1E) ⋯ N(5), and O(5)–H(5D) ⋯ O(4) (− x , − y + 1, − z + 1) to display a 2D (4,4) grid layer as sql topology (see Fig. S6 ). Finally, these layers are stacked into a 3D framework by interlayer π–π interaction between two phenyl rings of adjacent benzoic acids, as well as two triazole rings of 3-abpt ligands with perpendicular and centroid-to-centroid distance of 3.357(2), 3.739(8) Å and 3.429(2), 3.868(5) Å, respectively ( Fig. 4 b). A computation of these layer voids by using the platon program suggests a value of 518.1 Å 3 , corresponding to 30.4% of the unit-cell volume. 3.5 Synthesis Four new 3-abpt-metal-polycarboxylate coordination polymers have been isolated by using different reactive routes, namely, (i) direct assembly in water/methanol/DMF solution under the ambient condition and crystallization via solvent evaporation for compound 1 and 4 ; (ii) hydrothermal synthesis at 140 °C for compound 2 and 3 . We also tried to prepare compound 1 by hydrothermal synthesis. But it failed. During the reaction process, we found the metal-to-ligand ratio is a key factor for the preparation of these crystalline materials. 3.6 Infrared spectra The compounds 1 – 4 contain 3-abpt, carboxylate, coordinated water, and lattice water, which are in agreement with their IR spectra. The broad absorption bands from 3400 to 3200 cm −1 are assigned to coordinated or lattice water with strong hydrogen-bonding interactions. In the IR spectrum of 1 , the asymmetric stretching vibration ν as (COO − ) was observed at 1564 cm −1 , and the symmetric stretching vibration ν s (COO − ) was at 1367 cm −1 . These peaks were shifted to lower values compared with the carbonyl frequencies of free 1,2,4,5-H 4 beta. The absence of the band around 1730 cm −1 for a protonated carboxylic group shows that the carboxyl groups of the organic acid are completely deprotonated. In compound 2 and 3 , the ip ligand exhibits ν as (COO − ) strong absorptions at 1614, 1599 cm −1 and ν s (COO − ) strong absorptions at 1383, 1373 cm −1 , respectively. The compound 4 shows ν as (COO − ) absorption at 1558 cm −1 and ν s (COO − ) absorption at 1383 cm −1 . Their formulas have been confirmed by elemental analysis data and X-ray structural analysis. 3.7 Thermal stability As shown in Fig. S7 for TGA curves, compound 1 loses lattice water and coordination water in the range 100–150 °C with an endothermic peak at 126 °C (found: 7.81%, calc.: 7.24%). The remaining substance is thermally stable upon heating to 300 °C. Over the temperature of 350 °C, the observed weight loss of 32.56% is attributed to the elimination of beta ligands (calc.: 33.52%). The final residue should be ZnO. Compound 2 releases all lattice water in the range 110–180 °C with an endothermic peak at 154 °C (found: 11.75%, calc.: 10.36%). The remaining substance is thermally stable upon heating to 200 °C, following by a series of weight losses, until possibly a final residue ZnO formed. In the TGA curve of 3 , the first weight loss of 13.59% in 100–140 °C corresponds to the removal of lattice and coordination water (calc.: 13.35%), with an endothermic peak at 117 °C. The remaining substance is thermally stable upon heating to 300 °C. Further heating to 750 °C reveals a continuous weight loss of the sample. The TGA curve of 4 is analogous to the curves of others, showing the first weight loss of 2.99% in 90–110 °C that refers to lose of two lattice water molecules. The second weight loss of 3.47% in 100–150 °C corresponds to the removal of remaining water molecules that have some weak coordination interaction with Cu2 center. Further heating to 750 °C possibly led to the final residue CuO formed. 3.8 Photoluminescent properties The luminescent properties of several 3-abpt-metal-polycarboxylate coordination polymers explored by others indicate that emission colors of organic spacers were remarkably affected by their incorporation into metal-containing coordination compounds [14–21] . Thus, we reported herein the photoluminescence of compound 1 in the solid state under room temperature. As shown in Fig. S8 , upon excitation of the solid sample at 360 nm, intense band in the emission spectrum is observed at 440 nm. To understand more thoroughly the nature of this emission band, the luminescence of 3-abpt ligand was also investigated. For 3-abpt, the emission maximum is present at 388 nm. Even though there is a significant shift in the emission wavelength for the bound ligand, it probably come from intraligand π–π* transitions. 4 Conclusions In this work, phenyl-polycarboxylic acids from monodentate to polydentate are introduced to construct with versatile building block 3-abpt obtaining four diversity configuration. Compound 1 is 3D structure with bbf-3,4-Cccm topology. Compounds 2 – 4 are all 1D chains, but exhibit a variety of structures. In contrast to the three different 1D chains mentioned above, although using the same ligand and metal, two different structures of compounds 2 and 3 appear. One is tubular-like chain and the other one is ring-like network. It can be seen that the diverse coordination number of zinc center result in the difference. In compound 2 , Zn(II) atom is in a disorder tetrahedron coordination environment. While in compound 3 , Zn(II) centers display an octahedral geometry. Steric hindrance and spatial effect might effect the arrangement of the same ligand at the same time. When we using the benzoic acid ligand instead of isophthalic acid, 1D zigzag chain of 4 is obtained, in which benzoic acids serve in terminating roles, restricting the spatial extensions of structure. However, when using the μ 4 -bridging beta ligands, we found 3D compound 1 , in which beta ligands exhibit two different coordination modes. Comparing with other compounds, the μ 4 -bridging beta ligands result in the high dimensionalities of 1 . From above, we can see the structural discrepancy is depended on many factors, such as subtle interplay of metal coordination preferences, ligand type, spatial extension, and steric constraints. They play important roles in the formation of these framework materials. This result undoubtedly discovers the tectonic effect of ligands in metal–organic frameworks. As expected, subtle interplay of metal coordination preferences, spatial extension, and steric constraints also effect on the construction of coordination networks. On the other hand, hydrogen bonding and aromatic stacking force in these four compounds might play important roles in molecular recognition and assembly. This work prompts us to achieve more functional materials by employing a bent ligand 3-abpt and other angular, linear or polydentate ligands, and further efforts on this perspective are underway. 3WMJ0RN6.title: An efficient and highly stereoselective synthesis of novel trifluoromethylated trans-dihydrofuro[2,3-c]pyrazoles using arsonium ylides
3WMJ0RN6.abstract: An efficient approach of highly stereoselective synthesis of novel trifluoromethylated trans-4,5-dihydrofuro[2,3-c]pyrazoles has been described. Arsonium bromides 1 reacted smoothly with the electron-deficient alkenes (Z)-4-aryl-1-phenyl-3-(trifluoromethyl)-1H-pyrozol-5(4H)-ones 2 to give products trans-dihydrofuro[2,3-c]pyrazoles 3 with high stereoselectivity and in good to excellent yields, using CH 2Cl 2 as solvent and K 2CO 3 as base. © 2011 Elsevier Ltd.

sjodfiyt.title: A facile and convenient way to functionalized trifluoromethylated spirocyclic[indole-3,4-pyrano[2,3-c]pyrazole] derivatives
sjodfiyt.abstract: An efficient and consecutive one-pot, two-step, four-component reaction for the synthesis of trifluoromethylated spirocyclic[indole-3,4-pyrano[2,3-c] pyrazole] derivatives by the reaction of isatin, malononitrile, ethyl cyanoacetate, or cyanoacetamide, ethyl 4,4,4-trifluoroacetoacetate and hydrazine in the presence of a catalytic amount of piperidine in good yields was described. The structures of new compounds were determined by spectroscopic methods, microanalysis, and X-ray diffraction analysis. In addition, a possible mechanism of the reaction was proposed herein. © 2013 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.

oq3YYoTY.title: Three-component synthesis of novel trifluoromethyl-containing tetrahydropyran derivatives
oq3YYoTY.abstract: l -Proline-catalyzed reaction of ethyl 4,4,4-trifluoroacetoacetate, cinnamaldehyde and anilines provide a novel method for preparation of ethyl-6-(arylamino)-2-hydroxy-4-phenyl-2-(trifluoromethyl)tetrahydro-2H-pyran-3-carboxylate derivatives in good yields. The reaction was conducted by initial Michael addition, followed by intra-molecular cyclization under mild conditions. The structure of a typical ethyl-2-hydroxy-4-phenyl-6-( m -tolylamino)-2-(trifluoromethyl)tetrahydro-2H-pyran-3-carboxylate ( 4h ) was confirmed by XRD analysis. A plausible mechanism is presented.

YDlRsAhy.title: Highly stereoselective synthesis of trans-4-trifluoromethylsulfonyl-2,3-dihydrofurans from arsonium ylides and (E)-α-trifluoromethylsulfonyl-α,β-unsaturated ketones
YDlRsAhy.abstract: The reactions of arsonium bromides with (E)-α- trifluoromethylsulfonyl-α,β-unsaturated ketones in the presence of Cs2CO3 or K2CO3 proceeded smoothly under refluxing condition in dichloromethane (DCM) to give the corresponding trifluoromethylated trans-2,3-dihydrofurans in good to excellent yields with high stereoselectivity. © 2010 Elsevier Ltd. OxWtpSKP.title: Synthesis, structure and characterization of neat Zn2(OH)2 diamond-core chains linked through 2,2′,4,4′-biphenyl-tetracarboxylate
OxWtpSKP.abstract: Zn 3 (μ 3 -OH) 2 (2,4-bptc)] n ·2nH 2 O ( 1 ) was synthesized from 2,2′,4,4′-biphenyltetracarboxylic acid (2,4-H 4 bptc) and Zn(NO 3 ) 2 · 6H 2 O in the presence of NaOH hydrothermally. Crystal structure indicates that 1 is Zn 2 (OH) 2 diamond chains linked through 2,2′,4,4′-biphenyltetracarboxylate. 1 was characterized by TG, IR and fluorescence spectra. 1 is the first example of 2,4-H 4 bptc complex and also first complex contains Zn 2 (OH) 2 diamond-core chains. Abstract Reaction of 2,2′,4,4′-biphenyltetracarboxylic acid (2,4-H 4 bptc), Zn(NO 3 ) 2 · 6H 2 O in the presence of NaOH hydrothermally at 180 °C affords the first 2,4-H 4 bptc complex [Zn 3 (μ 3 -OH) 2 (2,4-bptc)] n · 2nH 2 O (1). Crystal structure indicates that 1 is Zn 2 (OH) 2 diamond-core chains linked through 2,2′,4,4′-biphenyltetracarboxylate. 1 was characterized by TG, IR and fluorescence spectra. 1 is the first example of 2,4-H 4 bptc complex and also first neat Zn 2 (OH) 2 diamond-core chains. Keywords 2,2′,4,4′-Biphenyltetracarboxylic acid Zn 2 (OH) 2 diamond-core chains Crystal structure Hydrothermal synthesis The crystal engineering of supramolecular architectures based on metal and organic building blocks has been rapidly expanding in recent years owing to their novel and diverse topologies and potential applications in host–guest chemistry, catalysis, electrical conductivity, and magnetism [1] . Multicarboxylate ligands have been proven to be good candidates because they can be regarded not only as hydrogen-bonding acceptors but also as hydrogen-bonding donors, depending upon the number of deprotonated carboxylic groups [2] . Of the aromatic carboxylates, 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate, 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylate, 1,2,4,5-benzenetetracarboxylate have been studied extensively. More recently, porous coordination polymers assembled from larger carboxylates, such as biphenyldicarboxylate, biphenyl-3,5,3′,5′-tetracarboxylic acid(3,5-H 4 bptc) complexes [3–6] and 3,4-H 4 bptc complexes have been reported ( Scheme 1 ) [2,7,8] . On the other hand, molecular metal oxide complexes can serve as valuable models in various areas, including surface–substrate interactions in heterogeneous catalysis, metal oxide/hydroxide particles in porous solids, deposition, precipitation, and condensation reactions that lead to M x O y framework structures [9] . High oxidation-state metal hydroxide/oxide complexes exhibit a variety of frameworks, in which the metal centers are shielded by anionic organic ligands. Complex hydroxide/oxides of +I and +II metal ions bearing more than two hydroxide/oxide centers are rare [9,10] . Oxygen bridged dimetal complexes M 2 (μ-X ) 2 (X = O, OH, or OH 2 ) is called diamond-core. Diamond-core structure play an important role in a number of important enzyme and metalloprotein systems, such as methane monooxygenase [11–13] . Maggard reported a pillared hybrid solids with access to coordinatively unsaturated metal sites [14] . Zn–(μ 3 -OH)–Zn diamond-core linked through a octahedral Zn has been reported by Loiseau et al. [15] . Phosphate bridged Zn–O chain also been reported [16] . To our knowledge, Zn 2 (OH) 2 diamond-core chain is still unknown. Here we report the first coordination polymer assembled from 2,4-H 4 bptc. It is a neat Zn 2 (OH) 2 diamond-core chains linked through bptc 4− . This is the first coordination polymer of 2,4-H 4 bptc. Compound [Zn 3 (μ 3 -OH) 2 (2,4-bptc)] n · 2nH 2 O ( 1 ) resulted from Zn(NO 3 ) 2 · 6H 2 O, 2,4-H 4 bptc and 1 mol/L NaOH hydrothermally at 180 °C for 3 days [17] . Crystal structure analysis [18] shows that there are three Zn ions in asymmetric unit ( Fig. 1 a). Zn1 coordinated to three carboxylate oxygens and one hydroxido oxygen to form a tetrahedron coordination environment. Zn2 and Zn3 ate both coordinated to five oxygen atoms. Zn2 coordination to two three carboxylate oxygen and two hydroxido oxygen while Zn3 coordinate to two carboxylate oxygen and three hydroxido oxygen atoms. The τ value for Zn2 and Zn3 are 0.14 and 0.36, respectively, which indicates that Zn2 is essentially square-pyramidal and Zn3 in a distorted square-pyramidal [19] . Each L 4− coordinates to six Zn(II) ions. Interestingly, Zn 2 (OH) 2 forms diamond-core and the diamond-core is linked via O10–Zn3 to form a neat diamond-core chain as shown in Fig. 1 b. Zn1 binds to the diamond-core chain via hydroxido O9. The diamond-core has a dihedral angle 65.55(23)°. The Zn–O–Zn angles in the diamond-core are 99.36(11) and 97.72(11), while the O–Zn–O angles are 80.64(11) and 82.28(11), respectively. The Zn3···Zn3 and Zn2···Zn2 distances in the diamond-core are 3.152(2) and 3.132(2) Å, respectively. All other Zn–O–Zn angles out side the diamond-core, ranges from 111.36(13) to 136.54(15), are larger than that in the diamond-core chain. The two benzene rings in the L 4− have a dihedral angle of 76.91(55), which is almost perpendicular to each other. The O2 and O5 of 2- and 2′-carboxylate oxygen coordinate to Zn2 simultaneously to form a 9-membered ring ( Fig. 1 b). Therefore, the 2- and 2′-carboxylate can be considered in cis -conformation. The O5–C9–O6 carboxylate is almost perpendicular to the benzene ring (98.04°). The other 2-carboxylate has a dihedral angle (with benzene ring) of 36.81(53)°. Both of the 4-carboxylates, O4–C8–O3 and O7–C16–O8 are almost coplanar to the benzene ring (2.18–5.27° torsion angle). It can clearly see that the complex is composed of Zn 2 (OH) 2 chains linked through fully deprotonated 2,4-bptc 4− . As shown in Fig. 1 c, each 2,4-bptc 4− binds to three Zn 2 ( OH ) 2 2 + diamond-core chains. The 2- and 2′-carboxylate binds one Zn 2 ( OH ) 2 2 + chain. One the 4-carboxylate binds a Zn 2 ( OH ) 2 2 + diamond-core chain via O3 and O4, the other 4-carboxylate binds third Zn 2 (OH) 2 2+ chain via O7 ( Fig. 1 d). The distances between adjacent chains are 9.94, 11.43 and 16.97 Å, respectively ( Fig. 1 d). The thermal stability has also been examined by TGA analysis and is shown in Fig. s1 . The crystal easily lost crystalline water molecules. Two crystalline water molecules completely lost at 202 °C (obs. 5.6%; calcd. 6.0%). The complex further lose 7.1% corresponding to CO 2 (7.4%) [20] . Further increase temperature leads to completely decompose of the framework. The IR spectra of the zinc complex ( Fig. s2 ) shows characteristic bands of carboxylate groups at 1617 cm −1 for the asymmetric stretching and at 1434 cm −1 and 1404 cm −1 for symmetric stretching. The separation ( Δ ) between ν asym (COO) and ν sym (COO) are 183 cm −1 and 216 cm −1 , respectively, indicating that carboxylate is coordinated with Zn atoms not only in a monodentate fashion, but also in a 1, 3-bidentate bridging fashion. The 1002 cm −1 peak can be attributed to the bending vibration of OH − in the complex. [21] These data are consistent with the crystal structure. Solid state emission/excitation spectra at room temperature shows significant red-shift in complex 1 compared free ligand 2,4-H 4 bptc due to deprotonation of the ligand in complex ( Fig. 2 ). Free 2, 4-H 4 bptc has an emission maximum at 423 nm (excited at 358 nm); while in complex this maximum is 442 nm (388 nm excitation). Excitation spectra in free ligand shows two peaks at 351 nm and 358 nm, while in complex, these maximum shifted to 391 nm and 409 nm ( Fig. s3 ). Due to Zn(II) is not a redoxable ion, we attribute all the fluorescence to ligand emission/excitation. Solid State Chem. 179 2006 573 [17] Synthesis of [Zn 3 (μ 3 -OH)2(2,4-bptc)] n · 2 n H 2 O (1): A mixture of Zn(NO 3 )2 · 6H 2 O (0.30 mmol, 89.4 mg), 2,4-H 4 bptc (0.10 mmol, 33.0 mg) and 1 N NaOH (0.60 mmol, 0.60 mL) was stirred half an hour. It was then placed in a 15 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel and heated at 180 °C for 3 days. Upon cooling to room temperature at a rate of 10 °C h −1 , colorless crystals of 1 were obtained with yield 33.5% based on Zn(NO 3 ) 2 . FTIR (KBr, cm −1 ): ν ˜ = 3621(w), 3558(w), 3430(vs, b), 1617(vs), 1546(m), 1434(m), 1404(vs), 1384(s), 1263(w), 1176(w), 1002(w), 825(w), 781(w), 718(m), 588(w) and 461(w). Anal. Calcd for C 16 H 12 O 12 Zn 3 : C, 32.44; H, 2.04. Found: C, 32.73; H, 1.98. [18] Crystal data for 1: M = 592.37, Triclinic, P -1, a = 8.4319(10), b = 10.2379(12), c = 12.1489(14) Å, α = 72.3340(10)°, β = 70.310(2)°, γ = 75.9450(10)°, V = 929.24(19), Z = 2, Dc = 2.117 g/cm 3 , R 1 = 0.0324, wR 2 = 0.0638 ( I > 2 σ ( I )); R 1 = 0.0429, wR 2 = 0.0689 (for all data). The diffraction data were collected with a Bruker Smart Apex CCD area detector with graphite-monochromatized Mo Kα radiation ( λ = 0.71073 Å) at 20 °C. The structure was solved by direct methods using SHELXS-97 and refined by full-matrix least-squares fitting on F 2 . Hydrogen atoms were added geometrically (CCDC 692244). [19] A.W. Addison T.N. Rao J. Reedijk J. Van Rijn G.C. Verschoor J. Chem. Soc. Dalton Trans. 1984 1349 [20] Y.-H. Lin M.O. Adebajo R.L. Frost J.T. Kloprogge J. Therm. Anal. Calorim. 81 2005 83 [21] K. AB3luJKs.title: Synthesis, structure, luminescence and magnetic property of camphorate coordination polymers containing 5, 6-dimethylbenzimidazole auxiliary ligand
AB3luJKs.abstract: Hydrothermal reactions of D-(+)-camphoric acid (D-H2cam) and 5, 6-dimethylbenzimidazole (dmbi) with metal salts afforded three coordination polymers, namely [Cd2(D-cam)2(dmbi)4]n (1), [Zn2(D-cam)2 (dmbi)2]n (2) and [Co(D-cam) 1/2(L-cam)1/2(dmbi)]n (3), which were characterized by elemental analysis, IR, PXRD, CD, thermogravimetry and X-ray structural analysis. Complexes 1 and 2 are homochiral coordination polymers. 1 is a 1D left-handed helical chain coordination polymer constructed from tri- and tetra-dentate camphorate. 2 exhibits a 2D polymeric network assembled by tri-dentate camphorate, which belongs to 3-connected {4.82} topology. 3 is a 2D achiral coordination polymer assembled by left-and right-handed 1D Co-camphorate helical chains. It is rarely observed that D-cam ligand changes to L-cam under hydrothermal condition. Three complexes are all thermally stable up to 316-425 °C. 1 and 2 show violet luminescence originating from ligand-centered emission. 3 exhibits an antiferromagnetic interaction in Co II 2 dimer withJ = -4.34 cm 1. © 2013 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.

Xy24muiE.title: Ethyl 5-[6-(furan-2-yl)-1,2,4-triazolo[3,4-b][1,3,4]thia-diazol-3-yl]-2,6-di-methylnicotinate.
Xy24muiE.abstract: In the title compound, C(17)H(15)N(5)O(3)S, the plane of the triazolo-thia-diazole system forms dihedral angles of 15.68 and 4.46° with the planes of the pyridine and furan rings, respectively. In the mol-ecule, there is an intra-molecular C-H⋯N inter-action. The crystal structure also contains other inter-molecular inter-actions, such as C-H⋯O hydrogen bonds, π-π stacking (centroid-centroid distances = 3.746 and 3.444 Å), non-bonded S⋯N [3.026 (2) Å] and C-H⋯π inter-actions.

4ORoU753.title: Synthesis, crystal structure and fluorescent property of two-dimensional Cu(I) coordination polymers with cyanide, thiocyanate and triazole bridges
4ORoU753.abstract: Hydrothermal reaction of CuCN, K 3[Fe(CN) 6] with 4-(6-amino-2-pyridyl)-1,2,4-triazole (apt) afforded a coordination polymer [Cu 7(CN) 7(apt) 2] n (1), while solvothermal reaction of CuSCN with apt in acetonitrile afforded a coordination polymer [Cu 2(SCN) 2(apt)] n (2). Complex 1 shows two-dimensional polymeric network with large hexagonal channels constructing by CuCN chains and tridentate apt ligands. Complex 2 shows two-dimensional polymeric framework assembled by ladder-like [Cu(SCN)] n chains and bidentate apt ligands, in which thiocyanate acts as a tridentate bridging ligand. Both polymers are thermal stable and strong fluorescent in the solid state. © 2007 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.

EhSdHrJo.title: Highly stereoselective synthesis of β,γ-disubstituted and α,β,γ-trisubstituted butyrolactones
EhSdHrJo.abstract: β,γ-Disubstituted butyrolactones were produced effectively and steroeselectively from arsonium ylides generated in situ and substituted olefins. The transformation could be realized in one-pot or in two steps, which depended on the electronic properties of the olefins. With the adjustment of the solvent and in the presence of EtOH, α,β,γ-trisubstituted butyrolactones were also obtained in high yield from arsonium ylides and substituted olefins. © 2008 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.

bTqxUpy7.title: Crystal structures and properties of four coordination polymers constructed from flexible pamoic acid
bTqxUpy7.abstract: Four novel coordination polymers constructed from flexible pamoic acid, namely [Co(pam)(4,4′-bipy)] n · n H 2 O ( 1 ), [Ni(pam)(4,4′-bipy)(H 2 O) 2 ] n ·2 n CH 3 CN ( 2 ), [Cd(pam)(py) 2 ] n · n py ( 3 ) and [Mn 2 (pam) 2 (py) 6 (H 2 O) 2 ] n ·2 n py ( 4 ), (H 2 pam = pamoic acid, 4,4′-bipy = 4,4′-bipyridine, py = pyridine), have been synthesized and characterized by elemental analysis, infrared spectra and X-ray crystallography. Complex 1 is a 2-D coordination polymer constructed from chelating bis-bidentate pam and 4,4′-bipyridine bridging ligands. Complex 2 is a 2-D coordination polymer assembled by bis-monodentate pam and 4,4′-bipyridine, where acetonitrile is filled in the rectangle channels. Both 2-D coordination polymers display undulated (4,4) grid layers as sql topology. Complex 3 displays a 1-D polymeric chain using chelating bis-bidentate pam as bridging ligand. Complex 4 exhibits an interesting bis-monodentate pam-Mn(II) 1-D polymeric chain, in which exist two-type six-coordinated manganese centers. Mn(1) is bound to four pyridine ligands, whereas Mn(2) is combined to two pyridine and two H 2 O molecules. Their thermal stabilities have been investigated. Cadmium complex 3 displays strong green luminescence with emission maximum at 543 nm. Keywords Coordination polymer Pamoic acid 4,4′-Bipyridine Crystal structure Thermal analysis Luminescence 1 Introduction The construction of coordination polymers has evoked considerable attention and become a quite active research field due to their diverse and intriguing polymeric structures with potential applications as functional materials [1–4] . The final structures of coordination polymers are dependent mainly upon the geometrical and electronic properties of ligands and metal ions, and also strongly influenced by other factors such as counter-ion, solvent, pH value, temperature, and metal-to-ligand ratio [5,6] . In particular, aromatic polycarboxylate and N-heterocyclic ligands have been shown to be good building blocks in the design of coordination polymers with desired topologies owing to their rich coordination modes and H-bonding interactions. 4,4′-Methylenebis(3-hydroxy-2-naphthoic acid) (pamoic acid, Scheme 1 ) is used in the pharmaceutical industry as a counter ion to obtain long-acting formulations of certain basic drugs [7,8] . In spite of pamoic acid is a common industrial precursor, its coordination behavior is not very clear to date. Pamoic acid is a multifunctional ligand containing both carboxylic and phenoxy groups, which has one half-molecule in the asymmetric unit and the two naphthyl rings are linked with a methylene bridge. H 2 pam as a bridging ligand possesses both flexibility and rigidity, since two napthyl rings can freely rotate at different degrees across the methylene (–CH 2 –) group, which can potentially exhibit various coordinate modes and diverse frameworks. Several H 2 pam complexes have been synthesized and structurally characterized [9–12] . Most of them contain chelating phen and 2,2′-bipy as co-ligands. With the aim of further understanding the coordination behavior of pamoic acid, we have prepared four new H 2 pam coordination polymers. Herein, we report their synthesis, crystal structures, thermal stabilities and luminescence. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials and methods All chemicals were analytical grade and obtained from commercial sources without further purification. Elemental analyses for C, H and N were carried out with a Vario EL III elemental analyzer. Infrared spectra were recorded with a Nicolet A370 FT-IR spectrometer using KBr pellets in the 4000–400 cm −1 region. The powder X-ray diffraction data were recorded on a Rigaku DLMAX-2550 diffractometer. Thermal analyses were completed on a Mettler Toledo TGA/SDTA85e thermal analyzer at a heating rate of 10 °C min −1 in nitrogen. Luminescent spectrum was recorded on a Shimadzu RF-5301 spectrophotometer. 2.2 Synthesis of complexes 2.2.1 [Co(pam)(4,4′-bipy)] n · n H 2 O ( 1 ) A mixture of Co(NO 3 ) 2 ·6H 2 O (0.117 g, 0.4 mmol), pamoic acid (0.077 g, 0.2 mmol), 4,4′-bipyridine (0.031 g, 0.2 mmol) and NaOH (0.016 g, 0.4 mmol) in 10 mL ethanol/H 2 O (v/v = 4:1) was placed in a 15 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel reactor, which was sealed and heated in an oven at 140 °C for 72 h. Red block crystals of 1 were obtained in 28% yield (0.035 g, based on H 2 pam). Anal. Calc. for C 33 H 24 CoN 2 O 7 : C, 63.98; H, 3.91; N, 4.52. Found: C, 63.56; H, 4.19; N, 4.32%. IR (KBr, cm −1 ): 3406m, 2937w, 1637m, 1608s, 1539s, 1458s, 1402s, 1324s, 808s, 757m. 2.2.2 [Ni(pam)(4,4′-bipy)(H 2 O) 2 ] n ·2 n CH 3 CN ( 2 ) A mixture of Ni(NO 3 ) 2 ·6H 2 O (0.043 g, 0.15 mmol), pamoic acid (0.039 g, 0.1 mmol), 4,4′-bipyridine (0.016 g, 0.1 mmol) and NaOH (0.008 g, 0.2 mmol) in 10 mL acetonitrile/H 2 O (v/v = 1:4) was placed in a 15 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel reactor, which was sealed and heated in an oven at 140 °C for 72 h. Light green block crystals of 2 were obtained in 42% yield (0.030 g, based on H 2 pam). Anal. Calc. for C 37 H 32 NiN 4 O 8 : C, 61.78; H, 4.48; N, 7.78. Found: C, 61.26; H, 4.14; N, 7.36%. IR (KBr, cm −1 ): 3469s, 2258m, 1638m, 1613s, 1576s, 1508m, 1461s, 1401s, 1343s, 1231m, 826s, 751s. 2.2.3 [Cd(pam)(py) 2 ] n · n py ( 3 ) An aqueous solution (2 mL) containing Cd(NO 3 ) 2 ·4H 2 O (0.062 g, 0.2 mmol) was dropped slowly into a stirred pyridine solution (5 mL) containing pamoic acid (0.039 g, 0.1 mmol) and 1,10-phenanthroline (0.018 g, 0.1 mmol). The resulting mixture was allowed to stand at room temperature. Slow evaporation for 1 week afforded light yellow prismatic crystals of 3 in 57% yield (0.042 g, based on H 2 pam). Anal. Calc. for C 38 H 29 CdN 3 O 6 : C, 62.01; H, 3.97; N, 5.71. Found: C, 61.68; H, 3.99; N, 5.77%. IR (KBr, cm −1 ): 3440m, 2930w, 1638s, 1547s, 1452s, 1396s, 1349s, 812s, 749s, 700m. 2.2.4 [Mn 2 (pam) 2 (py) 6 (H 2 O) 2 ] n ·2 n py ( 4 ) An aqueous solution (2 mL) containing MnSO 4 ·H 2 O (0.051 g, 0.3 mmol) was dropped slowly into a stirred pyridine solution (5 mL) containing pamoic acid (0.039 g, 0.1 mmol) and 4,4′-bipyridine (0.016 g, 0.1 mmol). The resulting mixture was allowed to stand at room temperature. Slow evaporation for 2 weeks afforded yellow block crystals of 4 in 50% yield (0.039 g, based on H 2 pam). Anal. Calc. for C 86 H 72 Mn 2 N 8 O 14 : C, 66.58; H, 4.68; N, 7.22. Found: C, 65.83; H, 4.62; N, 6.76%. IR (KBr, cm −1 ): 3068m, 1639s, 1597m, 1554s, 1456s, 1394s, 1351s, 810m, 744s, 699s. 2.3 X-ray crystallography The single crystal X-ray diffraction measurements of 1 – 4 were carried out on a Bruker Smart Apex-II CCD diffractometer with graphite monochromatic Mo Kα radiation ( λ = 0.71073 Å) using both ϕ and ω -scan modes at 296(2) K. Determinations of the crystal system, orientation matrix, and cell dimensions were performed according to the established procedures. Lorentz polarization and absorption correction were applied. The structures were solved by the direct methods and refined on F 2 by full-matrix least-squares techniques with SHELXTL -2000 program [13] . All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically, and hydrogen atoms were placed geometrically and refined using the riding model. The crystal data and structural refinements are summarized in Table 1 . Selected bond distances and angles are given in Table 2 . The measured and simulated powder X-ray diffraction patterns of coordination polymers 1 – 4 are shown in Fig. S2 ( supplementary data ). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Synthesis and infrared spectra Pamoic acid has poor solubility in many common solvents at room temperature. Complexes 1 and 2 were prepared by solvothermal reactions of H 2 pam and metal nitrates in the presence of 4,4′-bipyridine and NaOH in mixed solvent systems. The 4,4′-bipyridine and pam dianion play bridging ligands in the resulting coordination polymers. Complexes 3 and 4 were prepared by solvent evaporating method involved H 2 pam and metal salts in a pyridine-water mixed solvent system. The pyridine can act as an organic base and monodentate ligand in the reactions. Although 1,10-phenanthroline and 4,4′-bipyridine were respectively added to the reaction mixtures of 3 and 4 , however, both complexes contain none of them. Only pam dianion and pyridine coordinate to metal ions to form polymers. The absence of characteristic absorption of ν as (COOH) near 1700 cm −1 indicates that pamoic acid is completely deprotoned in 1–4 . The ν as (COO − ) vibrations of carboxylate groups occur at 1637, 1638, 1638, and 1639 cm −1 for 1–4 , respectively. While those of ν s (COO − ) occur at 1402, 1343, 1395, and 1351 cm −1 , respectively. The Δ(ν as − ν s ) different values of 235 cm −1 for 1 and 243 cm −1 for 3 are much smaller than those of 295 cm −1 for 2 and 288 cm −1 for 4 , which are consistent with the chelating bis-bidentate carboxyl coordinate mode in 1 , 3 , and the bis-monodentate mode in 2 , 4 ( Scheme 1 ) [14,15] . Their formulas have been confirmed by elemental analysis and X-ray structural analysis. 3.2 Description of crystal structures 3.2.1 [Co(pam)(4,4′-bipy)] n · n H 2 O ( 1 ) X-ray structural analysis revealed that complex 1 is a two-dimensional coordination polymer formed by 4,4′-bipyridine and pam bridging ligands. As shown in Fig. 1 a, the cobalt center adopts a distorted octahedral geometry, coordinated by two nitrogen atoms from different 4,4′-bipyridine and four oxygen atoms from two pam ligands. Both 4,4′-bipyridine ligands are arranged in cis conformation with a N(1)–Co(1)–N(2) angle of 101.1(2)°. Average Co–N bond distance is 2.080 Å. It is obviously less than the Cd–N distance of 2.335(3) Å in a 3-D coordination polymer [Cd 5 (OAc) 4 (OH) 2 (pam) 2 (4,4′-bipy) 2 ] n [14] . Both carboxyl groups of pam adopt the chelating bis-bidentate coordination mode ( Scheme 1 a). The Co–O bond distances vary from 2.026(4) to 2.424(5) Å. Previously, Du et al. have structurally characterized two 2-D coordination polymer [Cu(pam)(4,4′-bipy)(dmf) 2 ] n and [Cd(pam)(4,4′-bipy) 2 ] n · n H 2 O, in which 4,4′-bipyridine ligands coordinate to metal ions in trans conformation [10] . The V-shaped pam dianion acts as a tetradentate ligand to link up two cobalt ions to form a 1-D zigzag chain. The dihedral angle between both naphthyl rings is 84.1°. The adjacent 1-D chains are further connected by 4,4′-bipyridine linkers to form a 2-D double-layered polymeric network ( Fig. 1 b). It displays an undulated 2-D (4,4) grid layer as sql topology ( Fig. 1 c). Both hydroxide groups of pam are uncoordinated and bound to carboxyl O(2) and O(4) with strong hydrogen bonds of O(3)–H(3)⋯O(2) 2.547(5) Å and O(6)–H(6)⋯O(4) 2.594(5) Å. The packing diagram is shown in Fig. 1 d, which is porous and incorporated lattice water in the channels. 3.2.2 [Ni(pam)(4,4′-bipy)(H 2 O) 2 ] n ·2 n CH 3 CN ( 2 ) Complex 2 is a two-dimensional coordination polymer formed by 4,4′-bipyridine and pam bridging ligands. As shown in Fig. 2 a, the nickel center is six-coordinated by two nitrogen and four oxygen atoms, forming a distorted octahedral geometry. On the equatorial plane, two 4,4′-bipyridine ligands are arranged in cis conformation with a N(1)–Ni(1)–N(1A) angle of 91.5(1)°. The Ni–N bond distance is 2.073(2) Å. Two aqua molecules coordinate to nickel ion with Ni–O bond distance 2.064(2) Å. The pam dianion exhibits the bis-monodentate coordination mode ( Scheme 1 b). Two monodentate carboxyl groups occupy the axial positions with Ni–O bond distance 2.083(2) Å. This is obviously different with the coordination structure of 1 . Each pam bidentate ligand links two Ni(II) centers to form an infinite polymeric chain along a axis ( Fig. 2 b). The dihedral angle between both naphthyl rings is 77.8°. Such 1-D chains are further linked by 4,4′-bipyridine to form a 2-D polymeric network. It also displays an undulated 2-D (4,4) grid layer as sql topology ( Fig. 2 c). The 2-D layered networks are arranged in a parallel fashion to afford 1-D rectangle channels, in which the guest CH 3 CN molecules filled ( Fig. 2 d). Both hydroxide groups of pam are uncoordinated, and bound to carboxyl O(1) with strong intramolecular hydrogen bond of O(3)–H(3)⋯O(1) 2.514(3) Å. The carboxyl O(2) combines O(1W) through H-bond of O(1W)–H(1WA)⋯O(2) 2.635(3) Å. 3.2.3 [Cd(pam)(py) 2 ] n · n py ( 3 ) Complex 3 is a one-dimensional coordination polymer. As shown in Fig. 3 a, the cadmium center is in a distorted octahedral geometry, coordinated by two pyridyl nitrogen and four oxygen atoms from two chelating carboxyl groups. Average Cd–N bond distance is 2.29 Å. Cd–O bond distances vary from 2.321(6) to 2.348(7) Å. The pam dianion adopts the chelating bis-bidentate coordination mode. Each pam tetradentate ligand links two Cd(II) ions to form a 1-D infinite chain along a axis ( Fig. 3 b). The Cd⋯Cd separation is 11.755(3) Å. Every Cd(II) center is bound by two pyridine ligands in cis fashion. The N(1)–Cd(1)–N(2) bond angle is 88.7(2)°. The 1-D polymeric chains are parallel stacked as shown in Fig. 3 c. There exist uncoordinated pyridine molecules in the crystal lattice. Both hydroxide groups of pam are uncoordinated and bound to carboxyl O(2) and O(5) with strong hydrogen bonds of O(3)–H(3)⋯O(2) 2.560(7) Å and O(4)–H(4)⋯O(5) 2.557(7) Å. The flexible skeleton of pam is twisted and the hydroxy and carboxyl groups adopt a trans conformation to minimize the steric hindrance. The dihedral angle between both naphthyl rings is 82.6°. The uncommon cis conformation of pam was observed in [Zn(pam)(phen)] n [12] . Comparing the structures of 1 and 3 , both metal centers are cis six-coordinated by two pyridyl groups and two chelating carboxyl groups. Two 3-hydroxy-2-naphthoate pieces of pam are arranged in similar trans conformation. Different with the 1-D polymeric chain of 3 , the complex 1 displays a 2-D polymeric layer by introducing bridging 4,4′-bipyridine ligand. 3.2.4 [Mn 2 (pam) 2 (py) 6 (H 2 O) 2 ] n ·2 n py ( 4 ) Complex 4 displays an interesting 1-D polymeric chain, in which exist two-type manganese coordination centers. As shown in Fig. 4 , each asymmetric unit contains two independent Mn(II) ions, two pam ligands, two coordinated aqua molecules, and six coordinated pyridine as well as two lattice pyridine molecules. The Mn(1) center adopts a centro-symmetric octahedral coordination geometry, being surrounded by four pyridine and two monodentate carboxylic groups in trans configuration. Mn(1)–N bond distances vary from 2.279(4) to 2.316(4) Å. Mn(1)–O distance is 2.156(3) Å. The Mn(2) center is also in a centro-symmetric octahedral geometry, but coordinated by two pyridine [Mn(2)–N 2.318(5) Å], two H 2 O molecules [Mn(2)–O 2.160(5) Å], and two monodentate carboxyl groups [Mn(2)–O 2.150(3) Å] in trans configuration. Each pam dianion adopts the bis-monodentate coordination mode to bridge Mn(1) and Mn(2) ions. This leads to the formation of a 1-D polymeric chain. The Mn(1)⋯Mn(2) separation is 15.419(4) Å, which is obviously longer than the Cd⋯Cd separation in 3 . The dihedral angle between both naphthyl rings is 86.1°. The 1-D polymeric chains are arranged in a parallel fashion as shown in packing diagram. Uncoordinated pyridine is incorporated in the crystal lattice. Both hydroxide groups of pam are uncoordinated and bound to carboxyl O(2) and O(5) with strong hydrogen bonds of O(3)–H(3)⋯O(2) 2.537(5) Å and O(6)–H(6)⋯O(5) 2.532(5) Å. Unlike the well-known 2,2′-dihydroxy-1,1′-binaphthyl (binol) ligand which contains coordinated hydroxide groups, the hydroxide groups of pam are free in all reported pam compounds. Pam prefers to form 1-D polymeric chains with the metal ions, which can be extended to 2-D coordination polymers by introducing bridging ligands such as 4,4′-bipyridine. 3.3 Thermal stabilities and luminescence Thermal analyses for coordination polymers 1–4 were performed in the temperature range of 20–800 °C. Their TGA curves are shown in Fig. S3 . Complex 1 lost 2.86% lattice water near 50 °C (calc. 2.90%). [Co(4,4′-bipy)(pam)] n is stable up to 350 °C, and then released 4,4′-bipy and pam ligands. The resulting residue is Co 2 O 3 (found 13.59%, calc. 13.40%). Complex 2 lost two lattice acetonitrile molecules in 150–200 °C (found 11.32%, calc. 11.41%). The 4,4′-bipy and pam ligands released after 350 °C. The final residue is NiO (found 12.61%, calc. 10.10%). Complex 3 released lattice pyridine before 150 °C (found 11.63%, calc. 10.75%). Two coordinated pyridine molecules released in 170–270 °C (found 22.49%, calc. 21.50%). Pam ligand decomposed in the temperature range of 300–600 °C (found 49.75%, calc. 50.32%). The final, thermal stable residue is CdO (found 16.13%, calc. 17.45%). Complex 4 lost coordinated water near 110 °C (found 2.24%, calc. 2.32%). In the range of 120–320 °C, the complex 4 lost two lattice pyridine and six coordinated pyridine molecules with a total weight-loss of 42.48% (calc. 40.78%). Pam ligand decomposed in 320–800 °C (found 49.75%, calc. 50.32%). The final residue is MnO 2 (found 13.71%, calc. 11.21%). Comparing the structures and thermal stabilities of above four pam coordination polymers, pam adopts chelating and bridging coordinate mode, which leads to higher thermal stability. Usually, pam ligand starts to decompose after 320 °C [17] . Generally, d 10 transition metal complexes display varied luminescence in the solid state. Organic ligands and their coordination modes obviously affect their emission wavelengths and luminescent mechanisms. We have determined the luminescence of cadmium complex 3 . Upon excitation at 378 nm, this compound exhibits strong green luminescence with maximum emission peak at 543 nm ( Fig. S4 ). The free pamoic acid shows a weak emission peak at 473 nm. Generally, ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT) is the most common assignment for the luminescence of cadmium complexes [16] . Most of naphthyl carboxylate–cadmium(II) complexes exhibit green luminescence [9,17] . So we assign the luminescent mechanism of 3 to a LMCT mechanism, where the electron is transferred from pam ligand to Cd(II). 4 Conclusions Four novel coordination polymers containing flexible pamoic acid ligand were synthesized. They possess 1-D and 2-D polymeric structures. Both carboxyl groups of pamoic acid adopt bis-monodentate and bis-bidentate coordination modes. This study demonstrates that pamoic acid is capable of coordinating metal centers through bifunctional carboxyl groups. Hydroxide groups of pam trend to form hydrogen bonds with carboxyl group or coordinated water. The pamoic acid is a valuable bridging ligand in constructing coordination polymers. Photoluminescence experiment shows that the pam cadmium complex is a good candidate for green emission material. Acknowledgments Financially supported by the Leading Academic Discipline Project of Shanghai Municipal Education Commission ( J50102 ), and the Natural Science Foundation of Shanghai ( 10ZR1411100 ). Appendix A Supplementary data Supplementary data CCDC 741972-741975 contain the supplementary crystallographic data for complexes 1–4 . 85pYK4Cu.title: Unprecedented cyclic [Mo6O19]2- cluster and five organic-inorganic hybrids based on polyoxomolybdates and 4-amino-3,5-bis(pyridyl)-1,2,4-triazole
85pYK4Cu.abstract: Five novel hybrid compounds, [Mo8O26Cu 2(4-abpt)2]n·4nH2O (1), (4-H2abpt)2[Mo8O26] (2), [Mo 8O26Cu2(3-abpt)2(H 2O)2]n (3), [MoO4Cu(3-abpt)(H 2O)]n (4), and [Mo6O19Co(3-abpt) 2]n·4nH2O (5) were prepared by reacting MoO3/(NH4)6Mo7O24 with 4-amino-3,5-bis(3/4-pyridyl)-1,2,4-triazole (3/4-abpt) and corresponding metal salts. Compound 1 is a 2D coordination polymer containing extended γ-[Mo8O26]4- and [Cu2(4-abpt) 2]4+ ribbons. Compound 2 is a supramolecular hybrid aggregate composed of H-bond linking β-[Mo8O26] 4- and 4-H2abpt2+. Compound 3 exhibits a 2D rectangular network constructed by isolated β-[Mo8O 26]4- clusters and [Cu2(3-abpt) 2]4+. In compound 4, each MoO4 2- anion links two Cu(ii) ions to form a S-type [CuMoO4]n chain, which is further linked by bidentate 3-abpt to form a 2D wave-like network. In complex 5, unprecedented cyclic [Mo6O19] 2- cluster links two neighbouring hexamolybdates and two Co(ii) ions to form a 2D [CoMo6O19]n network, which is further pillared by tetradentate 3-abpt to generate a 3D metal-organic framework. These compounds are thermally stable under 250°C. The composites of the final residues were analyzed by PXRD. © 2011 The Royal Society of Chemistry.

ZAGV4rUY.title: Synthesis and crystal structure of diethyl-2,6- dimethyl-3,5-diyl-(l-(2- chlorobenzoyl)-lH- pyrazole-3-diethyl-carboxylate)-pyridine
ZAGV4rUY.abstract: The reaction of hydrazine hydrate with a new aγ-diketone ester 3, derived from the reaction of 2,6-dimethyl-3,5-diacetyl-pyridine 2 with diethyl oxalate in the presence of sodium ethoxide, afforded the pyrazole derivative 4. Treatment of 4 with 2-chlorobenzoyl chloride gave diethyl 2,6-dimethyl-3,5-diyl- (l-2(chlorobenzoyl)-lH-pyrazole-3-diethyl-carboxylate) pyridine 5. Fine crystal of 5 suitable for XRD analysis was obtained form recrystalization in ethyl acetate. The crystal belongs to the triclinic system, space group Pi, with a = 1.0342(11), b = 1.2211(12), c = 1.5013(15) nm, α = 82.5190(10),β = 85.7960(10), γ = 85.3150(10)°, V= 1.8697(3) nm3, Dc= 1.173 g/cm3, μ = 0.219 mm-1, F(000) = 684, Z = 2, the final R = 0.0720 and wR = 0.2211.

tyVzUWVe.title: 4-[4-Amino-5-(4-pyrid-yl)-4H-1,2,4-triazol-3-yl]pyridinium 2,4,5-tricarboxy-benzoate
tyVzUWVe.abstract: The solution reaction of 4-amino-3,5-bis-(4-pyrid-yl)-1,2,4-triazole (bpt), benzene-1,2,4,5-tetra-carboxylic acid (H4betc) and Co(NO3)2·6H2O led to the formation of the title cocrystal compound Hbpt·H3betc or C12H11N6 +·C10H5O8 -, in which strong hydrogen-bonding inter-actions assemble the ions into a three-dimensional supra-molecular framework. © International Union of Crystallography 2007.

hjb8DfZ6.title: Chiral coordination polymers with SHG-active and luminescence: An unusual homochiral 3D MOF constructed from achiral components
hjb8DfZ6.abstract: Six new coordination polymers, namely, [Cd(SO4)(4-abpt)(H 2O)]n·3nH2O (1), [Cu3(CN) 3(4-abpt)2]n (2), [Cd(D-cam)(2-PyBIm)(H 2O)]n (3), [Co(D-Hcam)(cptpy)]n (4), [Cd(D-cam)(btmb)]n (5), and [Cd2(D-cam)(L-cam)(btmbb)] n (6) (4-abpt = 4-amino-3,5-bis(4-pyridyl)-1,2,4-triazole, D-H 2cam = d-camphoric acid, 2-PyBIm = 2-(2-pyridyl)benzimidazole, Hcptpy = 4′-(4-carboxyphenyl)-3,2′:6′,3″-terpyridine, btmb = 1,4-bis(1,2,4-triazol-1-ylmethyl)benzene, btmbb = 4,4′-bis(1,2,4-triazol- 1-ylmethyl)-1,1′-biphenyl), have been synthesized under hydro(solvo)thermal conditions. Their structures were determined by single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis and further characterized by elemental analysis, infrared spectra, powder X-ray diffraction, circular dichroism, and thermogravimetric analysis. Complex 1 features a 3D porous metal-organic framework, which is a rare example to obtain a homochiral compound from achiral components. Complex 2 exhibits a 2D polymeric network constructed from μ2-cyanide, μ2-4-abpt, and monodentate 4-abpt ligands. Complex 3 is a homochiral 1D helical chain polymer. Complex 4 displays a 1D ladder-like polymeric structure in which cptpy- is tetradentate and D-Hcam- acts as a side arm. Complex 5 displays a homochiral 2D network with (4,4) topology. Complex 6 shows a [Cd2(D-cam)(L-cam)] n (4,4)-connected network with a paddle-wheel Cd2(COO) 4 as node, which is further pillared by a btmbb spacer into a 3D metal-organic framework. d-Camphoric acid underwent racemization under hydrothermal conditions. Cd(II) complexes 1, 3, and 5 crystallize in chiral space groups, and their circular dichroism spectra exhibit obvious positive or negative Cotton effects. Moreover, 1, 3, and 5 are SHG-active, and the SHG efficiency, respectively, is 0.15, 0.4, and 0.4 times as much as that of KH 2PO4. All the complexes exhibit relatively high thermal stability. 1, 3, 5, and 6 emit violet luminescence originating from ligand-centered emission. © 2013 American Chemical Society.

7ZMWlEYG.title: Synthesis, crystal structures, thermal analysis and magnetic property of mono- and bi-nuclear 1,1-cyclobutanedicarboxylate copper complexes
7ZMWlEYG.abstract: Two new copper complexes, [Cu(cbdc)(phen)(H2O)]·2H 2O (1) and [Cu2(cbdc)(phen)2(H 2O)2](ClO4)2·H2O (2) (cbdc=1,1-cyclobutanedicarboxylate and phen=1,10-phenanthroline), were synthesized by reaction of cbdc with Cu(ClO4)2 and phen in ethanol aqueous solution. Complex 1 crystallizes in monoclinic system with space group P2(1)/c and a=0.9428(4) nm, b=1.2183(5) nm, c=1.6265(7) nm, β=102.418(5)°, V=1.8246(13) nm3, Z=4, R= 0.0445, wR 2=0.0947. The structure of 1 is discretely mononuclear, which is packed by π⋯π interaction forming a 3D supramolecular structure where Cu(II) ion is five-coordinated and has square-pyramidal coordination geometry. Its thermal decomposition procedure detail was studied by thermal analysis TG-DSC. Complex 2 belongs to monoclinic system with space group P2(1)/c and a=0.8897(3) nm, b=1.9130(8) nm, c=1.9936(8) nm, β=99.04(2)°, V=3.351(2) nm3, Z=4, R=0.0540, wR2=0.1102. The structure of 2 is a discrete binucleus, where Cu(1) is four-coordinated by phen and cbdc in a square-planar geometry while Cu(2) is five-coordinated by phen, one O of cbdc and two H2O, which can be best described as distorted trigonal-bipyramidal geometry. Cu(1) and Cu(2) are linked by carboxylic group of cbdc in a bidentate bridging fashion. Variable-temperature magnetic susceptibilities of 2 in 2-300 K showed that its magnetic behavior obeyed Curie law. © 2006 SIOC, CAS, & Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA.

GMjA5Hu5.title: A two-dimensional copper polymer constructed from rod-shaped ferromagnetic secondary building units
GMjA5Hu5.abstract: Rod-shaped magnetic Cu 3 SUBs with S = 3/2 are bridged by end–end azide ligands to form a 2D coordination polymer. Magnetic investigation shows the ferromagnetic coupling between Cu II ions and very weak antiferromagnetic interaction between clusters. Abstract On the basis of rod-shaped secondary building units (SBUs), a novel two-dimensional (2D) azide–copper polymer, [Cu 3 (N 3 ) 4 (anol) 2 ] ∞ ( 1 ; anol = aminoethanol), was synthesized and structurally characterized. Complex 1 is a neutral 2D coordination network consisting of trinuclear copper(II) clusters [Cu 3 (N 3 ) 4 (anol) 2 ] connected with the bridge of end-end (EE) azide group. Magnetic data analysis shows that a metamagnetic behavior is observed for 1 which is associated with significant ferromagnetic coupling intracluster over 4 K. Keywords Azide–copper Crystal structure Magnetic properties SBUs The coordination polymers construction of secondary building units (SBUs) have drawn more attention due to their various topologies of structures and fascinating properties, such as porosity, nonlinear optical property, and magnetism [1–5] . Since the SBUs have triangular, square, tetrahedral, and octahedral building-block geometries, which can show different spatial configurations and maintain their structural integrity throughout the self-assembly process, a variety of multi-dimensional coordination geometries can be found in the crystal structure of their complexes, i.e., one-dimensional (1D) [6] , 2D [7–11] , and 3D [12–17] . Thus it was implicated that the design of high-dimensional magnetic systems might be realized starting from magnetic SBUs. Indeed, Miyasaka group obtained a long-range ferrimagnetic ordering 3D polymers used Mn4 single-molecule magnet as the SBUs [18] and a few of magnetic compounds constructed from well-defined ferromagnetic precursors were subsequently reported [19,20] . Consequently, this strategy may provide new insights to the design of new magnetic materials by using magnetic SBUs to create bulk magnets. As we have known, some derivatives of aminoethanol reacting with copper(II) ions may easily produce ferromagnetic copper clusters [21–24] . In addition, azide ligand has been playing an important role in the design and synthesis of magnetic materials because azide bridge can mediate strong coupling between magnetic centres [25–29] . Therefore, in order to obtain the compounds with strong magnetic exchange between copper clusters, a two-dimensional polymer composed of rod-shaped Cu 3 SBUs directly linked by the azide ligands, [Cu 3 (N 3 ) 4 (anol) 2 ] ∞ ( 1 ; anol = aminoethanol) was prepared. Herein, we reported the synthesis, crystal structure and magnetic properties of 1 . The complex 1 was prepared by reaction of Cu(NO 3 ) 2 · 3H 2 O (48.5 mg, 0.2 mmol), aminoethanol (6.1 mg, 0.1 mmol) and NaN 3 (130.4 mg, 2 mmol) in methanol and water mixture for one month, giving brown crystals in a yield of 40% (based on Cu). Anal. Calcd (%) for C 4 H 12 Cu 3 N 14 O 2 : C, 10.03; H, 2.53; N, 40.95. Found: C, 10.00; H, 2.65; N, 40.89. Selected IR data (KBr, cm −1 ): ν = 2012, 2031 and 2102 for the azide group. X-ray structural analysis [30] revealed that complex 1 is a neutral, two-dimensional coordination network based on trinuclear copper clusters [Cu 3 (N 3 ) 4 (anol) 2 ] joined by end-end (EE) azide groups. As shown in Fig. 1 , the basic unit contains three Cu(II) metal centres arranged in linear that are bridged by two end-on (EO) azide ligands and two μ 2 -oxygen atom of two aminoethanol. In the unit, the Cu1 is five-coordination with a distorted square-pyramidal geometry, where one μ 2 -oxygen atoms and a nitrogen atom of two aminoethanol with two nitrogen atom of two EO azide groups form the basal plane, while a nitrogen atom of one EE azide bridge occupies the apical position. The Cu2 is four-coordination described as distorted square planar. The basal Cu–N bond lengths are in the range of 1.972–2.005 Å which is identical to Cu–azide compounds [32–35] , and the apical Cu–N bond lengths is 2.442(3) Å. The Cu–O bond lengths are 1.9535(19) Å and 1.9412(18) Å, respectively. As the key parameter for magnetic coupling between metal centres, the Cu(1)–N(1)–Cu(2) and Cu(1)–O(1)–Cu(2) bond angles are 96.79(10)° and 100.49(8)°. The central copper(II) atom Cu2 connected the two terminal copper(II) (Cu1 and Cu1A) by double bridges of EO azide and μ 2 -O atoms to generate a linear trinuclear clusters. The clusters act as rod-shaped SBUs and are joined into a 2D network by the EE azide groups in the bc plane ( Fig. 2 ). Each rod-shaped unit is directly connected to four neighboring rods through four EE azide bridges. The Cu⋯Cu separation through the EO azide bridges is 2.994 Å, and through the EE bridges is 5.011 Å. In the solid state, the 2D network extend to three-dimension architecture by four hydrogen bonds of N7–H7A⋯O1 (symmetry: x , − y + 3/2, z − 1/2), N7–H7B⋯N4 (symmetry: − x + 2, − y + 1, − z ), C2–H2A⋯N3 (symmetry: x − 1, y , z − 1), and C2–H2B⋯N3 (symmetry: x − 1, − y + 3/2, z − 1/2). Magnetic susceptibility measurements of the crystalline sample of 1 was carried out on a Quantum Design MPMS-XL7 SQUID magnetometer in an applied magnetic field of 2 KOe over the temperature range 1.8–300 K. For 1 , the χ M T versus T plot is shown in Fig. 3 . At room-temperature χ M T value is 1.36 emu K mol −1 , slightly larger than the spin-only value of 1.24 emu K mol −1 based on uncoupled Cu 3 unit ( S Cu = 1/2 and assuming g Cu = 2.1). When the system is cooled, the χ M T value gradually increases and then rapidly below 50 K up to a maximum of 3.16 emu K mol −1 at 4 K, indicating ferromagnetic coupling between Cu II ions with a ground state spin S T = 3/2. Below 4 K, χ M T shows a sharp drop to 0.96 emu K mol −1 at 1.8 K, suggesting antiferromagnetic coupling between Cu 3 units. An additional evidence of S T = 3/2 is observed from the field dependence of magnetization at 1.8 K ( Fig. 4 ), where the saturation magnetization is 3.04 Nβ mol −1 at 7 T. The sigmoidal shape of the magnetization curve is the signature of metamagnetic behavior [36,37] which is confirmed by the low-temperature M versus T plots at various fields in the inset of Fig. 4 . To estimate the magnetic coupling interaction between Cu II ions and the intermolecular interaction, the magnetic data can be simulated by the isotropic spin Hamiltonian H = −2 J ( S Cu1 S Cu2 + S Cu2 S Cu1A ), where J is the coupling constants mediated by double bridges of EO azide and μ 2 -O atoms in cluster. When mean field correction was taken into account, the van Vleck equation can be written as follows: (1) χ = Ng 2 β 2 4 kT × 1 + e 2 J / kT + 10 e 3 J / kT 1 + e 2 J / kT + 2 e 3 J / kT , (2) χ M = χ / [ 1 - ( 2 zj ′ / Ng 2 β 2 ) χ ] . With this rough model, the calculated results in the temperature range from 5 to 300 K give: g = 2.18(5), J = 10.6(4) cm −1 , and zj ′ = 0.38(1) cm −1 with R = ∑[( χ M T ) calc − ( χ M T ) obs ] 2 /∑( χ M T ) obs 2 = 5.2 × 10 −4 . The magnetic data are reasonable and can be rationalized in light of the structure. In compound 1 , Cu1 and Cu2 provide their d ( x 2 − y 2 ) magnetic orbitals extended along the basal plane of the copper ions. The N1 atom of EO bridges occupies equatorial coordination position to form ferromagnetic couplings. According to the density functional calculations, the coupling parameter J is involved in the structural parameters, such as the Cu(1)–N(1)–Cu(2) angle and the bond length of Cu–N azide . At the same time, the oxygen bridges in the basal planes mediate the antiferromagnetic exchange interaction due to the Cu(1)–O(1)–Cu(2) bond angles larger than 98° [38–40] . So the J value is actually a sum of two contributions from EO azide bridge and oxygen bridge, respectively, which has also been reported [41] . Because the axial Cu–N bonds between trinuclear entities are long with 2.442(3) Å, the mean field correction (zJ′) is very weak. In summary, we have described the syntheses, single crystal structure and low-temperature magnetic behavior of the azide–copper complex 1 . Complex 1 is a novel 2D azide–copper polymer constructed by end-end model azide bridges between rod-shaped Cu 3 SBUs. A metamagnetic behavior is observed for 1 which is associated with significant ferromagnetic coupling intracluster over 4 K. Acknowledgements This work was supported by Excellent Youth Teachers Foundation of Shanghai Municipal Education Committee and the Innovation Foundation of Shanghai University. Appendix A Supplementary material CCDC 700730 contains the supplementary crystallographic data for this paper. These data can be obtained free of charge from The Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre via www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif . Supplementary data associated with this article can be found, in the online version, at doi:10.1016/j.inoche.2008.12.014 . Appendix A Supplementary material Crystal Structure CIF/PLATON report. mls5tSUW.title: Facile one-pot three-component reaction to synthesize trifluoromethylated cyclopenta[b]pyran derivatives and their further transformation
mls5tSUW.abstract: A series of trifluoromethylated cyclopenta[b]pyran derivatives were synthesized efficiently from 1,3-cyclopentanedione, arylaldehydes, and ethyl 4,4,4-trifluoro-3-oxobutanoate via one-pot multi-component reaction catalyzed by NH 4OAc. This one-pot multi-component process comprises an initial Michael addition and a subsequent intramolecular cyclization reaction. The effect of catalysts and solvents on the reaction efficiency and the yield were investigated. The structure of product 4f was further confirmed by XRD analysis. Meanwhile, further transformation of hemi-ketal moiety to the corresponding dehydrated product is also studied. In addition, a possible mechanism of this reaction is proposed herein. © 2012 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.

sDOxgxQ7.title: Syntheses, structures and luminescent properties of four copper(I) cyanide coordination polymers based on 2-(n-pyridyl)benzimidazole ligands (n = 2, 3, 4)
sDOxgxQ7.abstract: Four copper(I) cyanide coordination polymers containing 2-( n -pyridyl)benzimidazole ligands, namely [Cu 2 (CN)(2-PyBIm)] n ( 1 ), [Cu 2 (CN) 2 (3-PyHBIm)] n ( 2 ), {[Cu 3 (CN) 3 (4-PyHBIm) 4 ] · 2H 2 O} n ( 3 ) and [Cu 5 (CN) 3 (4-PyBIm) 2 ] n ( 4 ), have been synthesized and characterized by X-ray crystallography. Complex 1 is a one-dimension coordination polymer in which 2-(2-pyridyl)benzimidazole is deprotonated and adopts a bridging tridentate coordination mode. Complex 2 has ladder-like structure in which 2-(3-pyridyl)benzimidazole does not deprotonate and acts as a bidentate bridge. Complex 3 displays a saddle-shaped helical chain constructed through μ 2 -cyanide group and the outstretched neutral 2-(4-pyridyl)benzimidazole monodentate ligand. Complex 4 shows two-dimension layer polymeric structure in which deprotonated 2-(4-pyridyl)benzimidazole acts as a tridentate bridging ligand. The cyanide groups in four complexes all act as bidentate bridging ligands. These complexes are thermal stable and display luminescence in the solid states. Keywords Copper(I) cyanide 2-( n -Pyridyl)benzimidazole Coordination polymer Crystal structure Thermal stability Luminescence

Qf0w3omO.title: Highly stereoselective synthesis of trans-1,2-cyclopropane derivatives from semistabilized arsonium ylides by phase-transfer-catalysis reactions
Qf0w3omO.abstract: Semistabilized arsonium ylides, generated in situ from the corresponding arsonium salts in the biphasic system of dichloromethane-50% aqueous sodium hydroxide, reacted smoothly with electron-deficient alkenes to afford trans-1,2-cyclopropane derivatives with high stereoselectivity. The synthesis of trans-1,2-cyclopropane derivatives in the presence of sodium hexamethyldisilazanide (1.0 M solution in THF) were also studied. © Georg Thieme Verlag Stuttgart.

qQQDQhXt.title: Stereoselective synthesis of sulfonyl-substituted trans-2,3-dihydrofuran derivatives via reaction of arsonium Ylides with α,β-unsaturated ketones
qQQDQhXt.abstract: Trans-2,3-dihydrofuran derivatives 3 or 4 substituted with a sulfonyl group were prepared with high chemoselectivity and good yields by [1+4]-addition reaction of α,β-unsaturated ketones 1 with arsonium bromide 2 in CH2Cl2 in the presence of potassium carbonate at room temperature. The structures of the products were characterized by IR, MS, 1H NMR, elemental analysis and single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis. A mechanism for the formation of products was also proposed.

hMrWqoMv.title: Coordination polymers of 1,3,5-Tris(triazol-1-ylmethyl)-2,4,6- trimethylbenzene: Synthesis, structure, reversible hydration, encapsulation, and catalysis oxidation of diphenylcarbonohydrazide
hMrWqoMv.abstract: Eight coordination polymers {[Co 3(L) 2(H 2O) 6Cl 6]·4H 2O} n (1), {[Co(L) 2Cl 2]·13H 2O} n (2), {[Cu 3(L) 2(H 2O) 6Cl 6]·4H 2O} n (3), {[Cu(L) 2Cl 2]·12H 2O} n (4), {[Zn(L) 2(H 2O) 2](NO 3) 2·4H 2O} n (5), {[Zn(L) 2(H 2O) 2](PF 6) 2·6H 2O} n (6), {[ZnL(mal)] ·3H 2O} n (7), and {[Zn 3(L) 2(fum) 3(H 2O) 6]·2H 2O} n (8) were synthesized by reactions of the flexible tripodal ligand 1,3,5-tris(triazol-1-ylmethyl)-2,4,6- trimethylbenzene (L) and/or fumaric acid (H 2fum)/malonic acid (H 2mal), with corresponding metal salts, respectively. The structures of these polymers were established by elemental analysis, IR, powder and single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis. Complexes 1 and 3 had an infinite two-dimensional (2D) honeycomb network. L as a cis-tridentate ligand coordinated to metal ions up and down alternatively. Complexes 2 and 4 possessed a one-dimensional (1D) chain hinged structure. L was a cis-bidentate ligand. Complexes 5 and 6 had a 2D network structure with (4,4) topology. L was a trans-bidentate ligand in 5, while in 6, L adopted a cis-configuration coordinated to metal ion bidentately. Complex 7 had a wavy 2D structure. L adopted a trans-configuration coordinated ion in the c-direction, while the malonate anion coordinated to metal ions in the b-direction in left- and right-helix alternatively. Complex 8 had an unusual 2D to three-dimensional (3D) interpenetration network structure. L was in trans-configuration coordinated to metal ions tridentately in the bc plane to form a ladder structure, and fumarate anion bridged the ladder in the a-axis to form a porous 2D coordination polymer. Adjacent 2D coordination polymers penetrated each other in the c-direction to form a 3D coordination with void dimensions consisting of 11 Å rhombic channels. The structures of 1 and 2 (or 3 and 4) indicate ligand/metal ratios had a significant influence on the structures of coordination polymers. The distinct structures of all these complexes demonstrated that the counteranions played an important role in the construction of coordination polymers. The isostructure between complexes 1 and 3, 2 and 4, and 5 indicate that the metal centers did not affect the structure of the complexes. Complex 8 with the characteristic of hydrophilic carboxylate groups and hydrophobic L was capable of absorbing water reversibly under 50 °C and encapsulating guest molecules, such as curcumin, diphenylcarbonohydrazide, and phenylfluorone, to form {(guest molecule) x ⊂ 8} n. (where x = 0.2-0.4). The encapsulation behavior of 8 had been studied by elemental analysis, IR, thermogravimetric analysis (TG), and X-ray powder diffraction patterns (PXRD). Complex 8 could heterogeneously catalyze the oxidation of diphenylcarbonohydrazide in the presence of H 2O 2 in ethanol effectively. The oxidation process was facile, efficient, and environmental friendly. © 2011 American Chemical Society.
